description: On January 23, 2020, the Coordination Office of Measures on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Cabinet Secretariat (Japan), established a website on "Countermeasures Against the Novel Coronavirus".
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 21, 2020, the Governor of Saitama (Japan) stated that "for now, the best strategy to prevent the spread of the virus is for everyone to avoid infection. By keeping the concepts of 'I will not infect others' and 'I will not be infected by others' in mind, one can easily protect their family and loved ones."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “b) Call on consumers and businesses to remain calm and refrain from overstocking, to ensure there are enough masks and other goods necessary for the people.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “d) Take necessary measures for children who have temporarily returned from China, including supporting their acceptance and preventing bullying at schools.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On March 10, 2020, Japan's Consumer Affairs Agency (CAA) issued a document calling for the public to exercise caution towards the purchase and use of products which claim to be effective in preventing COVID-19, particularly because many such products lack evidence supporting their effectiveness. This document urged the public to utilize infection prevention measures such as hand washing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 10, 2020, Japan's Consumer Affairs Agency (CAA) published a document calling on businesses producing products which claim to be able to prevent COVID-19 and platforms through which they are sold (e.g. online shopping sites) to take steps to improve the representation of their product on the grounds that many of these products lack evidence to substantiate such claims and may mislead consumers.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 12, 2020, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) issued a warning to warn against scams: "Counseling regarding fraudulent e-mails and phone calls using the "new coronavirus" is sent to the Consumer Affairs Counseling Service in the prefecture."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On March 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) published a webpage to inform foreign workers, especially those working as employees for companies in Japan, about their rights, welfare programmes, and opportunities for support during the coronavirus pandemic. Since then, the Ministry updated the page several times, adding information in several foreign languages and specific sections targeting other categories of foreign workers.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will work with the government in informing the residents that the emergency measures are different from "lockdown" (city blockade).”
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will “call for a calm response in order to prevent confusion including panic buying of food, medicine and daily necessities.”
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) published a summary on the "Current Status of Production and Supply of Face Masks, Antiseptics and Toilet Paper" in order to counteract the spread of false information concerning the shortage of said products.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Between April 7, 2020 to May 6, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) requested residents not to "buy up food, medical supplies, and daily necessities."
type_text: Request by prefecture government not to bulk buy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to “[i]nform the public that the government will not take measures such as "lockdown" (city blockade), and call for a calm response from the people (self-restraint of travel across prefectures, such as nonessential visits to hometowns and travel, avoiding flooding of shops and panic buying).”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) from April 8, "police warn people to be cautious" about "corona-linked fraud" and to "consult others when encountering such suspicious situations". For example, there had been cases of victims who "failed to receive surgical masks and other sanitation products they ordered online" and of "suspicious emails and phone calls offering corporate bonds" to develop corona cures.

On May 13, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) issued an announcement to its citizens that suspicious phone calls, emails and short messages (SMS), social networking services (SNS), websites, etc. regarding new coronavirus infectious diseases and special fixed benefit have been confirmed. "Please be careful of unfamiliar phone calls, e-mails, and websites so that you will not fall victim to crimes caused by these new coronavirus infections."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In regards to “9) Other common issues,” “[p]refectures will inform their residents that the emergency measures are different from the "lockdowns" (city blockades) that are being implemented in other countries, and they shall call for a calm response through asking people not to panic-buy food, medicines and daily necessities.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 22, 2020, Tottori Prefecture (Japan) issued a declaration prohibiting discrimination, prejudice, and slander against those infected by the coronavirus.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Municipal Government

description: On April 30th, the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that preschools, primary and secondary schools (secondary level I) would reopen under the condition that no external persons without explicit invitation would be allowed to enter the premises. This includes parents, external persons organizing/attending events and external organizations renting school rooms. The policy was scheduled to start on May 11th. On August 6th, the state government announced that from August 10th on, external organizations would be allowed to rent school rooms again outside of teaching time. UPDATE: The original policy banned external organizations from renting school rooms. This was changed to external organizations being allowed on school premises outside of teaching time.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In early August, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) initiated a campaign to create an advertisement that shows that infection risk can be eliminated by basic measures in buses, taxis, and trains, and we have begun posting them on the bodies of taxis, high-speed, chartered buses, etc.

description: On August 25, 2020, the draft “Ordinance on Cluster Measures for Preventing the Spread of New Coronavirus Infection in Tottori Prefecture” was approved after a revised decision at the extraordinary session in August 2 of the Tottori Prefectural Assembly (Japan). description:
On March 24, 2020, the Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) Koichi HAGIUDA sent to local authorities and prefectural education boards guidelines on the reopening of schools. The guidelines highlight that the following three conditions and their combination must be avoided:
- closed spaces with poor ventilation
- crowded spaces
- conversations at close distances
To avoid these conditions, MEXT calls for the use of masks and implementation of good ventilation, as well as temperature checks. Hand washing and coughing etiquette must be enforced.  

Furthermore, the guidelines take into consideration students who cannot attend school because they have been identified as an infected person, or having close contacts. It calls for the prevention of discrimination, prejudice and awareness for the mental health of children. 

Teachers and faculty must also not come to school if they are sick or have close contacts.

Extracurricular activities may continue but with adjustments so that the three conditions are avoided. 

To ensure that learning is not delayed, schools may offer supplementary classes with measures in place. 

The continued suspension of the school will be depended on local school authorities and must take into account, infections within the school and the surrounding community.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 1, 2020, the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) suggested "keeping schools closed, but sets no clear policy", thus "recommend[ing] continued closures of schools in areas with increasing numbers of novel coronavirus infections but again le[aving] the decision to local authorities". MEXT "sent revised guidelines to prefectural education boards nationwide concerning the reopening of schools".

The revised guidelines clarify how local authorities can decide whether to reopen schools for the start of the new term.

description:
Japan, on Apr. 13 Akita government announces the temporary closure of prefectural schools and Akita technical college. "Due to the outbreak of this infection, we decided to temporarily close the prefectural schools and Nishi Senboku High School in Akita City, Oga City, Katagami City, and Nanaki Area from today until April 26." "Prefectural schools have resumed classes on April 6th, except in some areas, but we will stop these schools for the time being to prevent the spread of infection. In addition, Akita Technical College in Akita City will also be temporarily closed from today until April 26."
 UPDATE: Closure of schools will be extended until Apr. 26. Furthermore in addition to prefectural schools Akita technical college and Nishi Senboku High School in Akita City, Oga City, Katagami City, and Nanaki Area will be closed too.

institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down

description:
On April 14, all the prefectural schools in Matsue City in the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) were temporarily closed for 14 days from April 15 to 28 by the governor to the prefectural board of education. "As requested by the Prefectural Board of Education, the prefectural high schools in Matsue City and 5 special support schools in Matsue City will be temporarily closed for 14 days. As of April 17, the closure of schools was extended to May 6.

Schools subject to temporary closure: Matsue Kita High School, Matsue Minami High School, Matsue East High School, Matsue Technical High School, Matsue Commercial High School, Matsue Agriculture and Forestry High School, Shinji High School
Blind School, Matsue Deaf School, Matsue Special School (Excluding branch classrooms), Matsue Seishin School, Matsue Midorigaoka School" UPDATE: The schools in Matsue in the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) were originally mandated to be closed from April 15 to April 28, but this has been extended to May 6.

description: On April 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has issued a directive to local authorities to ensure that day care centers look after children of healthcare workers who are on the frontlines of the coronavirus outbreak." description: On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On June 5, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published "Comprehensive Package for Ensuring Children's Learning in the COVID-19 crisis". 

This document stated that, as part of efforts to recover learning affected by COVID-19, schools should take measures including reviewing the length of long vacations, holding classes on Saturdays, setting special attendance days and redesigning timetables. Schools are also encouraged to make staggered attendance schedules and prioritize school events, shortening their preparation time.

institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 5, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published "Comprehensive Package for Ensuring Children's Learning in the COVID-19 crisis". 

This document stated that prefectural boards of education should show special consideration regarding high school entrance exams. Specifically, if a student's performance in club activities or other events is used for evaluation but events have been cancelled or postponed, evaluation can be done based on their performance in other activities they were able to participate in. 
Moreover, students should not be disadvantaged due to their school record showing fewer days of attendance or fewer descriptions of learning assessments.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

This document stated that MEXT is aiming to create an environment that enables all students to study from home online. MEXT aims to do this through actions such as contacting suppliers after grasping nationwide demand, and having specialists advise local governments. It was stated in addition that specific priority will be given to providing an ICT environment for final year students and families which cannot prepare an ICT environment due to financial difficulties.

description: On August 6, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published "COVID-19 cases at elementary and junior and senior high schools and the countermeasures based on this data". As part of (1) countermeasures against household transmission it was decided that schools should create an environment where it is easy for teachers to take time off. This is to be done by sharing information about the content and progress of work duties among teachers, as well as through devising ways to divide teaching duties among teachers if one is unable to come to work.

description:
On January 29, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published the document "Regarding thoroughness in efforts to prevent COVID-19 infection spread in universities". This document stated that, regarding graduation and enrollment ceremonies, universities need to judge whether or not to hold them based on the infection situation. 

In the event that these ceremonies are held, measures which universities are expected to take include: not having people with cold-like symptoms participate, encouraging participants' strict observance of mask-wearing and hand-washing rules, having sufficient ventilation of the venue, ensuring space between participants and shortening the ceremony as much as possible.

description: On May 22, 2020, it was announced that the Government of Japan "will support nine domestic studies aimed at developing a coronavirus vaccine with subsidies totaling 7.2 billion yen, or about 67 million dollars." "The funds are designed to support basic research and segments of clinical trials for an experimental vaccine. The nine projects were selected by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development. Four are led by companies; another four involve universities; and one, a research institute."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzō said that "Japan will provide about $300 million to a global organization dedicated to increasing access to vaccinations in developing countries. The financial support to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, will be extended for five years from 2021 to make contributions to global public health efforts. [...] The Japanese government provided around $95 million to Gavi for the previous five-year period from 2016 to 2020. The upcoming donation of $300 million, including $100 million already pledged in April, is the largest amount Japan has provided to the nongovernmental body to date."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On July 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has agreed to receive a supply of 120 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine for 60 million people by the end of June next year from U.S. pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE., if they succeed in developing the vaccine."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has agreed to receive a supply of 120 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine for 60 million people by the end of June next year from U.S. pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE., if they succeed in developing the vaccine." UPDATE: On January 20 2021, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) issued a press release stating that the MHLW had entered into a treaty with the company Pfizer to purchase an extra 24 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine. This is in addition to the 120 million doses that were purchased on July 31 2020, for a total of 144 million doses.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "adopted on Friday a plan to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for the whole population of the country by the first half of 2021. The plan was included in the government's policy for its future response to the COVID-19 crisis, adopted at a meeting of its task force on measures against the coronavirus. [...] The government will prepare a legal framework ensuring state compensation in case coronavirus vaccines cause side effects."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 9, 2020, AstraZeneca Plc announced that "global clinical trials of an experimental vaccine developed with the University of Oxford has been halted [...] citing 'a potentially unexplained illness' in one of its volunteer participants. A spokesperson for the Japanese arm of AstraZeneca said the pause would include Japan."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

A spokesperson for the Japanese arm of AstraZeneca said the pause would include Japan." UPDATE: AstraZeneca halts global COVID-19 vaccine trials due to illness.

description: On October 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "members of the public in Japan will be given a dose of vaccine against the novel coronavirus for free [...] in a bid to curb serious and fatal cases of infection. The policy addresses the first dose for everyone amid uncertainty at this stage over how many times a vaccine would need to be administered. Whether the policy will cover foreign residents in Japan has yet to be officially determined." "The government is trying to secure enough vaccines by the first half of 2021 to administer to all members of the public, having earmarked a budget of ¥671.4 billion ($6.4 billion)."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan "approved a bill to pay all costs to administer COVID-19 vaccination to all residents in Japan, and to compensate suppliers in the event any serious side effects occur. The bill to amend the current vaccination law is in line with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's pledge to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for everyone in the country in the first half of next year. [...] Once the government provides vaccines free of charge, residents will be strongly advised to get vaccinated. The government may choose to offer vaccines with limited effectiveness and let people decide whether they want to receive them."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 2, 2020, the Diet (the government of Japan) ‘enacted a bill to offer free vaccinations against the novel coronavirus’. Under this law, ‘the central government will shoulder costs for COVID-19 vaccinations while vaccination programs will be implemented by municipal governments.’ Furthermore, ‘the law also allows the state to conclude contracts with drugmakers so that possible compensation payments over health problems from the vaccinations will be made by the government for the makers’. This law also includes ‘a provision obliging citizens in principle to make efforts to get vaccinated against the coronavirus’, but the provision will not go into effect unless the ‘effectiveness and safety of vaccines are fully confirmed’.
type_sub_cat: Administering of the vaccine (i.e. giving people the vaccine shot)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced "that it has concluded an agreement with Moderna Inc. for the supply of a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the U.S. biopharmaceutical firm if it succeeds in developing the vaccine." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 50 million doses of the vaccine, enough for 25 million people, from Moderna in 2021 - 40 million doses in January-June and the rest in July-September. The value of the deal was not disclosed. The ministry also concluded a contract with Japan's Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. for the distribution and sales of the vaccine in the country."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 27, 2021, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) and local officials in Kawasaki City, Kanagawa Prefecture, ‘ jointly conducted a drill [...] to run a venue for novel coronavirus vaccination’. Around 60 people were involved in the drill, with ‘each wearing a bib bearing the name of the role they are playing such as “doctor” and “person to be vaccinated”’. The drill was successful, and was able to run at its target pace of ‘30 people per hour’.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On February 14, 2021, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) approved the use of the Pfizer vaccine within Japan to prevent Covid-19 infections. A special fast-track system has been used to grant approval as quickly as possible.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 8, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Defense announced that it had begun priority vaccinations of medical workers, beginning with the staff of the Self-Defense Forces Central Hospital.

description: On January 25, 2021, the Health Ministry of Japan announced that ‘Tickets for COVID-19 vaccinations will be sent to people aged 65 or older in Japan from mid-March’. According to the Ministry, ‘the vaccination tickets will be sent to about 36 million older residents, who are third priority for vaccinations’. Under this system, ‘municipal governments will input the numbers printed on the vaccine tickets sent to residents and their My Number IDs, used for social security and taxation purposes, while medical institutions will register the ticket numbers and information on vaccines administered to the residents’.
type_sub_cat: Administering of the vaccine (i.e. giving people the vaccine shot)

description: On February 13, 2021, major retailer Aeon Co. has announced that they will ‘let local governments use its shopping centers as venues for COVID-19 vaccinations’. This includes ‘Some 290 large facilities’, which ‘will be offered to municipalities struggling to secure sites for inoculations’. According to the announcement, the decision was made after ‘being asked by multiple local governments about vaccination venues’.

UPDATE: On February 5, 2021, the Governor of Mie Prefecture (Japan) SUZUKI Eikei announced the extension of the prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus until March 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage.” The critical period will span 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and businesses,” following the release of Fukuoka Prefecture from the state of emergency on February 28, 2021. Fukuoka Prefecture explained that because “the corona has not settled down yet. And as of March 3, 240 people, including 100 severely and moderately ill, continue to be hospitalized. Even though the bed usage rate is declining, it remains at 31.4%, which is equivalent to Stage III.” The announcement will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021

description: On January 31, 2020, at the Second Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that Japan "will deny entry of individuals who are infected by the virus in accordance with the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act. description: On May 12, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "in light of the various circumstances associated with the impact of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) and from the perspective of preventing its spread, as a measure to reduce congestion at the immigration counters for residency applications, the immigration counters will be accepting applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay from those foreign nationals (excluding foreign nationals with the status of residence of "Designated Activities (Departure Preparation Period")) whose expiration date (see note) for their period of stay is due in March, April, May June or July for an extended period of three months from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national."

description: At a press conference on June 23, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "it has been decided to operate special flights from Japan to Viet Nam over the three-day period on June 25, 26, and 27 arranged by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Viet Nam. Through these flights, it is planned for about 440 Japanese residents and businesspeople to travel to Viet Nam. They will be the first flights from Japan to Viet Nam since the agreement to relax restrictions partially and gradually on mutual travel between our countries. For this travel, the people who go to Viet Nam will enter the country in accordance with Viet Nam’s designated process of measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Also, among the travelers, businesspeople who will return to Japan after a relatively short time are expected to enter Japan in accordance with the trial measures for entry based on the decision made last week on June 18 by the National Security Council (NSC) and the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters. Specifically, on the condition that they comply with additional infection control measures, it is expected that measures will apply to them that enable limited business activities during the 14-day waiting period, such as waiting at home."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On June 26, 2020, the Immigration Service Agency of Japan announced the temporary extension of the validity of Certificates of Eligibility (CoE). Under these temporary measures, Certificates of Eligibility will be "treated as valid for 6 months from the date on which entry restrictions from the applicant’s country of residence are removed, or until 30th April 2021, whichever is the earliest, provided [that] the Certificate of Eligibility was issued between 1st October 2019 and 29th January 2021 and the visa applicant has not been able to apply for or receive a visa using their CoE within the normal 3-month validity period of the COE due to the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak. If an applicant intends to use a COE which is beyond 3 months from the date of issue for a visa application, they must submit a letter from their inviting organisation etc. in Japan (e.g. employer or university) stating that they are still willing to accept the applicant for the purposes stated in the application for the COE."
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Justice,Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 8, 2020, it was announced that "a Maritime Self-Defense Force unit stranded in Djibouti for around three months due to the COVID-19 pandemic will return to Japan in early July." "They will be flown back to Japan after a new unit, which consists of 60 or so personnel, arrives as early as mid-June to take over their duties."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 3, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan introduced "the Pre-Entry TB screening to be applied to nationals of countries with a high caseload of TB patients" (Philippines, Vietnam, China, Indonesia, Nepal, and Myanmar). "The TB screening will be implemented on or after July 1, 2020 in countries where necessary coordination is complete. It applies to any person from the above-mentioned countries who intends to stay in Japan for a mid-to-long-term period, either upon applying for the Certificate of Eligibility, or applying for a visa at a diplomatic mission abroad in the cases where the Certificate of Eligibility is not necessary for visa application." "If the applicant's current place of residence is proven to be outside a designated country or region by his/her identification card or relevant document issued by the country of residence, he/she will be exempted from screening."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 4, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "for organizations mainly conducting elementary and secondary education, from the perspective of ensuring the right of children to receive education, we will allow new entry and re-entry to Japan by human resources that are difficult to find adequate replacements for within Japan, as they have “special circumstances” that make them exceptions to denial to enter Japan. From this perspective, coordination has been conducted with related ministries and agencies to allow re-entry by teachers at international schools and their families who have status of residence in Japan, as well as entry into Japan by newly-appointed teachers."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On August 6, 2020, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki declared a second prefectural-level state of emergency regarding COVID-19. In this framework, Aichi Prefecture requested the residents in Aichi “not to go outside of Aichi Prefecture or have someone from other prefectures come to Aichi.” The request will take effect from August 6, 2020 to August 24, 2020.

The request will take effect from August 24, 2020.

description: From December 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "due to the effects of the new coronavirus infection, those who have difficulty returning to their home country and wish to work will be allowed to work within 28 hours a week (part-time job)." "Foreign nationals with 90-day short-stay visas can renew their permits and receive permission to work up to 28 hours per week. Additionally, technical trainees will be able to change their visas to a “specified activity” work permit for six months. Those with student visas will also be able to work up to 28 hours per week even if they are no longer students." "Employers in Japan should note that these measures are temporary and that their duration is unknown at this time."
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On December 26, the Government of Japan announced that the country “will temporarily suspend new entry into the country of nonresident foreign nationals from around the world” from December 28, 2020 0:00 JST until the end of January 2021 “as a precautionary step against the new, potentially more transmissible coronavirus variant.” “Japanese citizens and foreign residents will be allowed to enter.”
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description: On January 8, 2021, the Government of Japan announced that "all arrivals in Japan, including Japanese nationals, would be obliged to provide certification they tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure as well as take another test upon arrival at a Japanese airport." The measure will be enforced from January 13, 2021 and be effective "until a second state of emergency [...] is lifted. The government said the emergency declaration will run" through February 7, 2021.

description: On January 12, 2021, the Governor of Fukushima (Japan), UCHIBORI Masao enacted prefectural-level emergency measures due to the novel coronavirus in line with the prefectural assessment to raise the stage of alert of Fukushima to stage 3. In this regard, the Governor asked residents to refrain from travelling to and from the four prefectures under the national declaration of emergency (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Chiba) for non-essential and non-urgent reasons from January 13, 2021 until February 7, 2021.

description: On January 19, 2021, the Governor of Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) TAMAKI Denny "declared the third state of emergency" "over the novel coronavirus” from January 20, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Okinawa Prefecture requested citizens to refrain from non-necessary and non-urgent travelling between Okinawa and the areas affected by the national state of emergency or a prefectural-level state of emergency. As of January 18, 2021, the national emergency declaration covered Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama, Kanagawa, Osaka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Aichi, Gifu, Fukuoka, and Tochigi Prefectures; a prefectural-level state of emergency was issued in Nagasaki Prefecture (Nagasaki City only), Ibaraki, Mie, Kumamoto, and Miyazaki Prefectures.

description: On January 14, 2021, the Governor of Mie Prefecture (Japan) SUZUKI Eikei issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus. The state of emergency will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this regard, the Governor asked residents to avoid going to other prefectures, including those under a state of emergency or where reduced office hours are in place, except in cases of extreme need. UPDATE: On February 5, 2021, the Governor of Mie Prefecture (Japan) SUZUKI Eikei announced the extension of the prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus. Accordingly, this measure has been extended until March 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents to “refrain from going to other prefectures, especially to Tokyo, Osaka, and other prefectures where a state of emergency has been declared.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021. UPDATE: On February 22, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki began discussions with Japan’s Minister for Economic Revitalization NISHIMURA Yasutoshi to lift the national-level declaration of emergency for Aichi Prefecture by February 28, 2021. Accordingly, the requested period for this measure has been shortened to February 28, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage.” Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government requested residents to “refrain from going to other prefectures, especially to Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa, where the state of emergency is declared.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “Requests to residents of the prefecture (Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law)”, Fukuoka Prefecture requested residents to “refrain from unnecessary and non-urgent travel between prefectures and travelling to areas where the infection is spreading.” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage. Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government is requesting residents to “refrain from going to other prefectures, especially to Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa, where the state of emergency is declared.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021. UPDATE: On March 10, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 21, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, the number of flight passengers travelling to Japan will be constrained to control the number of people arriving in Japan.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From January 8, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture requests that residents who have symptoms such as coughing or fever after returning from Wuhan City should go to a medical institution.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 15, 2020, based on the data available until the morning of January 15, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) updated the guidelines on "standard precautions to be taken when examining patients with suspected cases of pneumonia of unknown cause in Wuhan” (firstly published on January 10, 2020). Accordingly, it recommended, if a moderate or severe pneumonia is diagnosed, to apply the guidelines for surveillance of suspected cases (updated by the NIID on January 10, 2020).
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided that (2) "if it is confirmed that a person is infected at a medical institution, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases should  arrange proper inspection and retrace the close contacts of the infected person."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided to (1) "implement national border control measures, such as checking the health status of people entering the country from areas with a high risk of infection, with tools such as thermographies at quarantine stations."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 28th, the Regional Health Division of Hokkaido asked citizens with suspected symptoms to "wear a mask and undergo a medical examination." Once having undergone examination, patients will be contacted with test results. Patients are asked to observe their health for 14 days, and in case of specified infections, are recommended to admit themselves to a hospital.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 28, 2020, the Hokkaido Department of Health issued a statement regarding the health monitoring of travellers. After surveying 22 travelling participants, the Department confirmed that two displayed symptoms of COVID-19. All travellers who have tested positive are requested to implement anti-infection measures in the hospital, and all Hokkaido citizens are requested to monitor their health, particularly those who plan to travel or come into contact with travellers.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[t]aking into consideration the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus despite exhibiting no symptoms, it is necessary for us to phase up our responses including quarantine measures. [...] We will introduce a measure, aimed at all people entering Japan with any history of travelling to Wuhan or related areas, that checks their contact information while in Japan and follows up on their health status, regardless of whether or not they have exhibited any symptoms."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 7, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government in conjunction with the special wards of Tokyo Metropolis, Hachioji City, and Machida City established a call center for Tokyo Metropolis residents with fevers or respiratory symptoms and/or those who have returned from abroad or had contact with returning residents.  Inquirers to this hotline may be referred for medical examination if they meet certain criteria.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 7, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) establishes a "Returnee and Contact Consultation Center" at 19 health centres in the prefecture to provide COVID-19 advice for returnees from overseas and their contacts.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 17, 2020, the Tuberculosis and Infectious Diseases Control Division of Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced new guidelines for consultations and medical examinations for Japanese residents who believe they may have had exposure to COVID-19, i.e. residents returning from abroad.  The guidelines urge residents with symptoms to stay home, record their body temperatures, and call a special consultation center if they meet certain criteria.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From February 20, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) advises that residents with "cold symptoms or high fever" (37.5 degrees Celsius or more) and/or continual "excessive fatigue or difficulty with breathing" for more than four days should phone a medical center for consultation. On the other hand, "elderly people and others who have underlying diseases" should phone if these symptoms continue for more than two days.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 20, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that all people with COVID-19 symptoms should go to a consultation center, rather than just people who travelled to Wuhan and have symptoms. UPDATE: Policy originally extended to people who went to Wuhan and have symptoms, but now extends to anyone who has symptoms.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 21, 2020, the Governor of Saitama Prefecture (Japan) announced that "Those who have cold-like symptoms and/or a fever (37.5°C and above) that persists for more than four consecutive days, please do not hesitate to seek consultation. In particular, the elderly, those who suffer from chronic illnesses, those who are pregnant, and those who feel severely fatigued or have difficulty breathing are recommended to seek consultation as soon as possible. If you suspect infection, please refer to the 'Consultation Centers for Persons Returning to Japan or Those Who May Have Been in Contact with New Coronavirus.'"
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to “(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan,” it was agreed to “B) Establish the surveillance system to grasp the epidemic situation in Japan, while switching to use of PCR test for the confirmation of diagnosis necessary to treat pneumonia patients who require hospitalization, in communities where the number of patients continues to increase."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “A) b) Encourage people to contact the Call Center for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts, which refer suspected patients to outpatient facilities from the viewpoint of accurately grasping the situations of outbreak and preventing the further spread, as seeking medical care without consulting due to the anxiety from potential infection may lead to increased risk of infection.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) The elderly and those with underlying diseases are encouraged to seek appropriate medical care at the early stage, given their vulnerability to the infection.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, prefectural governments “will provide guidance to school operators on infectious disease countermeasures such as health management.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 20, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) "has changed the definition of people who had close contact with patients of the COVID-19 disease, caused by the novel coronavirus. According to the new definition, people who were at a distance of one meter, enough to touch by hand, from an infected person for 15 minutes or more without taking infection prevention measures, such as wearing a face mask, two days before the person started to display symptoms or later are regarded as those with close contact with the patient."
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On May 1, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism commenced thermographic boarding checks at four airports - Narita, Chubu Centrair International Airport in Aichi Prefecture, Kansai
International Airport in Osaka Prefecture and Fukuoka Airport in Fukuoka. "Thermographic cameras are situated at the entrance to the security check areas for domestic flights.Passengers with body temperatures of 37.5 degrees or higher will be asked not to board and to consult a public health center." They will also receive a pamphlet on COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will "Identify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary."

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "7) Strengthening counter-cluster measures" it was decided that "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control."

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (3) matters shared by Prefectures under Special Caution and designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that, concerning infection prevention, prefectures will adopt contact tracing app and SNS technology and inform people that these technologies will allow the infection situation regarding the users of facilities to be grasped.

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In regards to “8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures,” “[a]ctive epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control.” To support this, “[e]xperts will be secured and trained to conduct the counter-cluster measures and strengthen the health center system. Technologies such as apps and social networking systems will also be utilized to promptly introduce a system for efficiently controlling infections and quickly grasping the infection situation.”

description:
Japan (Tokyo), on June 05, 2020, "in order to safely use the metropolitan facilities visited by many users, [the Tokyo Metropolitan Government] build a new 'Tokyo version of new corona watching service' from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of new coronavirus infection".
"This service is a mechanism that promptly notifies the user of infection information based on the visit history of the facility when a new coronavirus infectious disease cluster occurs in a metropolitan facility."
Targeted facilities include Metropolitan cultural facilities, sports facilities, gardens/zoos, libraries, etc. (will be expanded in the future).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 19, the Saga prefecture (Japan) announced that it will be using the mew coronavirus contact confirmation application (COCOA), developed to contribute to extended prevention of new coronavirus infectious disease in Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient." UPDATE: The contact tracing app was released on June 19, but due to technical issues the app was suspended on June 23.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 23, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "temporarily stop[ep] the app from issuing any alerts," as it "erroneously accepts reference numbers not issued by the Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry." "To prevent confusion, officials have halted the issuance of personal numbers. This means the app's contact-notification function will remain out of service. Officials say they plan to fix the flaw as soon as possible."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 26, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (Tokyo Prefecture, Japan) implemented the 'Store-type Tokyo version of New Corona Monitoring Service'. Commencing June 27, 2020, it will serve as an infection information notification service regarding cluster outbreaks of new-type coronavirus infectious diseases based on the history of visits to private stores by users", in cooperation with several Corona Tech partner companies (Event Resist Co., Ltd., Yahoo Japan Corporation, Ikkyu Co., Ltd.). The business will start on June 27, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 3, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "resumed its coronavirus contact-tracing app service." "The ministry says users need to update their app to the latest version." UPDATE: On July 3, 2020, the coronavirus contact-tracing app service was resumed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 15, Fukuoka Prefecture encourages residents to use COCOA, "a contract-tracing application developed to prevent the spread" of COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 22, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) established a branch office of the Traveler’s Access Center Okinawa (TACO) at Miyako Airport. The office will provide health consultations for visitors. If fever is confirmed, it will be possible, with the consent of the patient, to transfer with a dedicated car from the airport to Miyako Hospital in order to conduct a PCR test.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: July 28 2020, Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (2) the adoption of contact tracing apps, etc within 2) Efforts to encourage restaurant users adopt behaviour to protect themselves it was decided that people will be encouraged to download the COCOA contact tracing app and register to use local governments’ own notification systems.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will utilize more digital technologies to more efficiently detect and track cases.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 3, the Tottori Municipal Public Health Center (Japan) announced the planned implementation of the examination for the faculty members of Tottori City Higashi Junior High School and all the school students in relation to the 15th case positive in the prefecture (12th case of the Tottori City Public Health Center).
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On August 5, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) launched a coronavirus countermeasure security system. 

"If a person who is positive for the new coronavirus is found among the participants of a large-scale event held in Tottori Prefecture, a service will be sent from the prefecture to alert the recipients to the email address registered at the venue."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that it "plans to ask elderly facilities to simulate a coronavirus outbreak by the end of August, as part of its resurgence response." "Staff at the facilities will also be asked to check stock levels of sanitary goods such as disinfectant and face masks and how they are checking the health of the staff. With the steps, the ministry aims to prevent an infection cluster among elderly people with a higher risk of developing serious conditions." "Facilities will have to report to the ministry by early September on whether they have taken the steps. Facilities required to carry out such simulations are special elderly nursing homes, nursing care facilities, homes for the elderly with care services and other establishments where many old people live together."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of August 14, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will begin using its new "Hiroshima Corona News QR" service that uses QR codes to inform citizens that they may have contacted an infected person and supports them to have a PCR test to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infections.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “implement[s] regular screening all at once for all those who work at medical institutions and care facilities for the elderly so as to prevent group infections among people at high risk of developing severe symptoms.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 16, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "has been repeatedly urging the Bangladesh government to take adequate measures to protect all personnel engaged in the 84 Japanese-funded development projects around the country from Covid-19. It also wants the government to provide medical care to those who have been already infected. The organisation has written to the government's Economic Relations Division (ERD) three times so far on this issue."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to establish an infectious disease response center to monitor the health conditions of athletes participating in the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games in the summer of 2021. The agreement was struck at a meeting of a coordination council over the novel coronavirus epidemic among the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games." "The infectious disease response center, to be set up as part of the organizing committee, will check the health of Olympians and Paralympians throughout the sporting events. If athletes test positive for the novel coronavirus, the center will share necessary information with their national delegations and related sports organizations."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to set up a hub serving as a public health center and a fever clinic for outpatients. The council[, composed by the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games,] will start work on details, including securing staff personnel for the new bases." "The hub serving as a public health center is likely to be established in or near the athlete village, which will be used by up to some 30,000 people. If athletes or other people linked to the Tokyo Games are confirmed with the virus, the hub will conduct active epidemiological surveys in coordination with the infectious disease center and identify those who had close contact with the infected individuals."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On January 8, 2021, the Government of Japan announced that "all arrivals in Japan, including Japanese nationals, would be obliged to provide certification they tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure as well as take another test upon arrival at a Japanese airport." "Even if the tests confirm arrivals are not infected, authorities will ask them to pledge to [...] keep records of their location information." The measure will be enforced from January 13, 2021 and be effective "until a second state of emergency [...] is lifted. The government said the emergency declaration will run" through February 7, 2021.
type_sub_cat: A person’s absolute (e.g. GPS) location over time
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description: On January 8, 2021, the Government of Japan announced that "all arrivals in Japan, including Japanese nationals, would be obliged to provide certification they tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure as well as take another test upon arrival at a Japanese airport." "Even if the tests confirm arrivals are not infected, authorities will ask them to pledge to download a contact-tracing app." The measure will be enforced from January 13, 2021 and be effective "until a second state of emergency [...] is lifted. The government said the emergency declaration will run" through February 7, 2021.

description: On February 18, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) released a bug fix update for the COCOA contact tracing application. This update mainly fixed bugs concerning Android users and certain iOS users not receiving notifications from the app when coming into contact with individuals who had tested positive for COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, regarding the follow-up measures by Immigration Health Confirmation Center, it was stated that the country will expand the target of the measures to all arrivals and thoroughly carry out the health observation and order arrivals to wait at home by confirming their location information and condition throughout video call and doing patrol in case of being unable to contact with arrivals for 3 days or more.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. Beginning on March 22, 2021, the prefecture recommended operators at facilities for the elderly, as the occurrence of clusters in facilities for the elderly is the biggest factor in the increase in the number of hospitalised people, to monitor the health status of workers on a daily basis.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On January 31, 2020, the Ministry of Defence of Japan (MOD) "issued an order to send SDF personnel to deal with mass infections at the Diamond Princess cruise ship quarantined off the coast of Japan. This mission was completed on March 16." The Self-Defence Force (SDF) carried out disaster relief activities and livelihood support. The vessel "Hakuo" will be used as a base for SDF personnel.
On January 31, 2020, Saga Prefecture (Japan) announced that it will ship 9,000 masks to Guizhou and Liaoning provinces in China.
type_text: Humanitarian aid in the form of masks sent to China
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "[e]ven for those individuals who have tested negative, [the Government is] thoroughly monitoring health condition of each and every person under appropriate controls, by stationing doctors at all accommodation facilities on a round-the-clock basis, [and] also providing push-mode support for daily living essentials, including face masks, sanitizers, thermometers, and other daily items, to those privately-owned accommodations and government facilities who have pledged their cooperation."

description:

description: On February 7, 2020, it was reported that "the Government of Japan decided to provide China with 4,800 safety goggles and 5,200 isolation suits, which are part of the equipment stockpiled by Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and financed by Japan’s contribution, as in-kind contribution from the Government of Japan. This in-kind contribution was transported to Wuhan by the chartered flight which left Japan on Wednesday, February 6, and handed over to the Chinese side at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport on Thursday, February 7."

description: Since February 10, 2020, "Yokohama [(Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan)] has set up a call center to handle inquiries about the coronavirus." The call center is open from 9 a.m.-9 p.m., seven days a week, including holidays."

description:
On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan announced additional efforts that are being made in response to the COVID-19 outbreak on the Diamond Princess Cruise Ship. 

The Government of Japan is building a screening structure "to enable screening to be carried out not only at public testing institutions such as the National Institute of Infectious Diseases and Public Health Institutes, but also at private testing institutions." 

Currently, screening capacity only exists for approximately 300 cases per day, but capacities to screen 1000 cases a day are expected by the end of the maximum latency period on February 18, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 20, 2020, Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) "published a webpage titled, "For Safe Travels in Japan: Guide for when you are feeling ill," which allows users to find medical professionals in their area that speak English, Chinese, and Korean, plus other languages (Polish, French, German) that are less available. It also includes a brief guide for how to use travel medical insurance and typical Japanese hospital procedures. The tourism site also launched the Bebot x JNTO chatbot, which gives users information on COVID-19, restrictions on travel from China, travel insurance, as well as the option to "speak to human.""

description: On February 20, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) announced that alongside using information from research bases in Asia (Vietnam, China, Thailand, Philippines, Indonesia, Myanmar), the Ministry will be subsidising research for the purpose of developing therapeutic agents and contributing to infectious disease control in Japan. 50 million yen will be distributed across six universities, namely Nagasaki University, Tokyo University, Osaka University, Tohoku University, Kobe University and Niigata University.

description:
