description:
On February 28, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) "has nominated the following 3 companies as the first group to be provided with subsidies for installing production equipment by the second week of March:
- Kowa Company Ltd. for manufacturing masks
- XINS Co. Ltd. for manufacturing masks
- Hata Industries for manufacturing components of masks
The above three companies already started production and aims to start an increase in production of face masks to about 15 million in total, supply of which will be for the coming month."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan ABE Shinzō held a press conference on COVID-19, where he announced that the Government is "proactively supplying reagents and other test kits to local public health institutes, private-sector screening institutions, and universities across Japan and working to build their capacity in this area. As a result, nationwide we have the ability to conduct more than 4,000 screenings daily. We continue to provide reagents to private-sector screening institutions and universities in areas outside the major cities and are working to enhance their screening capacity further."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 1, 2020, at the 16th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government "will materialize necessary response measures that include the development of a medical treatment structure, such as securing more than 5,000 hospital beds and installing the necessary facilities."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 8, 2020, it was reported that the "Government of Japan has provided a total sum of JPY 800 million (approx. Rs. 1,400 million) to the Government of Sri Lanka to strengthen the health sector to tackle COVID-19 through the provision of medical equipment. [...] Equipment procured under this grant include MRI scanners, CT scanners, X-ray systems, and Central Monitors, which will be immediately installed at the selected hospitals and treatment centers that have been leading the efforts in combatting COVID-19." "The Government of Japan has been providing medical equipment and technical assistance since March 2020 in response to the request from the Government of Sri Lanka."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 20, 2020, it was reported that, according to the Ministry of Justice of Japan (MOJ), inmates of "seven prisons in Aomori, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Yamaguchi and Kochi prefecture" have been sewing "cloth face masks" since March 2020. "Having received orders from private-sector companies, these prisons now have the combined capacity to sew some 66,000 such masks a month." "Protective gear, meanwhile, which is in short supply on the medical frontline, is being produced at prisons in Kyoto and Osaka, with around 4,600 sets to be dispatched monthly."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 2, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture requests that medical institutions prepare a COVID-19 patient acceptance system. This system is needed in the event that patient numbers increase in the prefecture and there are insufficient beds to treat them in the designated infectious disease medical institutions.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 3, Oita Prefecture announced that "health centres will be responsible for [COVID-19] consultations concerning diagnosis and precautionary measures".
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 3, Oita Prefecture announced that they have "designated 15 hospitals for outpatient consultations for individuals who have recently returned from overseas or may have come in close contact with a patient", as well as "18 medical institutions designated for infectious diseases" for inpatient treatment.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Hiratsuka City(Kanagawa, Japan) government distributed a total of about 25,000 masks to all 158 facilities including kindergartens, nursery schools, and after-school children's clubs in the city on March 3rd, 2020.

description: On March 5, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe declared that the Japan "intend[s] to secure 15 million facial masks as the Government, by asking companies in Japan to increase the production and expanding import from overseas." The "supply of facial masks in the domestic market" will be encouraged "by providing support to mask manufacturers to increase their production."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: At a press conference on March 17, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that Japan will provide "15 billion yen in contributions for international organizations" in order to implement "appropriate support measures" such as "technical cooperation and materials provision targeted at matters such as medical care, health workers, medical facilities, hospitals, and quarantine facilities".

description: On March 11, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI), launched a "free remote health consultation service to address COVID-19 related concerns" in order "for people to avoid visiting medical institutions only based on their concerns over the novel coronavirus disease without first appropriately consulting with experts and unnecessarily visiting any environments where people are more likely to be infected by the disease".

description: On March 11, 2020, in the framework of the "Cabinet Order for the Partial Revision of the Order for Enforcement of the Act on Emergency Measures for Stabilizing Living Conditions of the Public", Japan promulgated that, from March 15, 2020, "it is prohibited to [i] resell face masks that you have bought at retail stores, online shopping malls or other businesses [ii] to unspecified persons or a large number of people online or through stores or other businesses [iii] at prices higher than the acquisition prices."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) donated to "Bangladesh five Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) machines to ramp up testing facilities regarding Covid-19. Besides, the agency will provide the country with safety equipment to help fight the spread of coronavirus." "The demand to Jica through the ERD [Economic Relations Division] included 5 lakh [500.000] Personal Protection Equipment (PPE), 5000 hand-held thermometers, 10 lakh [1.000.000] sterile examination gloves and 3 lakh [300.000] units of safety goggles."

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[s]ecure a flexible medical provision system in each region, depending on the spread of infection” and to “[t]o prepare for possible significant increase of patients in Japan, secure medical provision structure including through considering division of roles among medical institutions in each region. Secure necessary beds, personnel, and necessary medical equipment such as respirators.”

description: On March 28, 2020, the Minister of Defense of Japan (MOD) KŌNO Tarō issued "an order to dispatch Self-Defense Forces troops as part of his country's efforts to strengthen quarantine steps amid the spread of the new coronavirus. From Saturday, the dispatched troops are engaged in the work to quarantine people arriving at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda and Narita International Airport in Chiba Prefecture, east of Tokyo. They are also supporting the transport of such people to designated facilities. The Defense Ministry dispatched SDF members on a voluntary basis based on a judgment that the current situation represents a case stipulated by the SDF law where the ministry should not wait for a dispatch request from a prefectural governor."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 30, 2020, Japan donated US$7 million to Iran through the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP. "WFP will use the US$7 million grant for its COVID-19 response to support Iranian health workers and strengthen the resilience of the refugee community in Iran." The first consignment consists of US$4 million in the form of medical equipment, including 370,000 three-layer masks,
370,000 N90 masks, and 370,000 scrubs which were delivered to the Iranian Red Crescent Society. The Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) was airlifted into Iran from the United Nations Humanitarian Response Depot in Dubai.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 8, 2020, the Japan Medical Association (JMA) announced that it will offer financial assistance to the medical support non-profit organization "AMDA Medical Information Center", which "will set up a multilingual hotline to help foreigners in Japan for inquiries regarding the new coronavirus" from April 10, 2020.

description:
On April 10, 2020, a not-for-profit organization, the "AMDA Medical Information Center" launched a "Multilingual Consultation Service Regarding COVID-19." The hotline is supported by financial assistance from the Japan Medical Association (JMA).

The hotline will be open until May 20, 2020 and will be available in English, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on weekdays, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on weekends and national holidays. Chinese will be available on weekdays only, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Also available in Korean, Tagalog, Thai, Spanish, Vietnamese and Portuguese on designated weekdays.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 11, 2020, Japan has announced measures to "ease the shortages of medical supplies at medical sites." "45 million surgical masks [will be distributed] to medical institutions nationwide; a further 10 million to these institutions in the seven prefectures" affected by the declaration of a state of emergency. "Regarding medical gowns and face shields, [...] 1 million of each [will] be distributed to the seven prefectures, subject to the degree of scarcity. As for N95 and KN95 masks, [...] 70,000 masks within next week and 700,000 by the end of the month [will be delivered]."

description:
The Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katsunobu Katō announced on April 10, 2020, that it "will allow first-time patients to receive medical examinations and prescriptions online or via telephone starting" on April 13, 2020. "Patients who choose to receive such services will [...] be able to get their prescribed medicines at home via courier after receiving instructions on their use from a pharmacist by telephone."

Prefecture-by-prefecture lists of medical facilities that offer services online or by phone are available on the website of the MHLW.

description: On April 14, 2020, Osaka Prefecture "began to treat mildly ill or asymptomatic patients of the novel coronavirus at a business hotel in the city of Osaka [...] in an effort to prevent the local medical system from collapsing amid the crisis. The prefectural government has set aside funds for 3,000 rooms for such people." Moreover, "13 hospitalized people moved to Super Hotel Osaka Natural Hot Springs. [...] Nurses will be at the hotel for full-time services to check patients' conditions every day and respond to any sudden changes in their conditions. At the hotel, 400 rooms are secured for coronavirus patients."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 14, 2020 the Osaka City Mayor Ichiro Matsui designated Osaka City Jūsō Hospital as a specialised COVID-19 hospital. Existing patients with illnesses other than COVID-19 will be transferred to other hospitals and vacant wards will gradually accept COVID-19 patients who are not seriously ill, but are experiencing mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Once all of the transfers and preparations are completed, the hospital will re-open as a specialised COVID-19 hospital although the date is not yet fixed.

description:
On April 14, 2020 the Osaka City Mayor Ichiro Matsui designated Osaka City Jūsō Hospital as a specialised COVID-19 hospital. Existing patients with illnesses other than COVID-19 will be transferred to other hospitals and vacant wards will gradually accept COVID-19 patients who are not seriously ill, but are experiencing mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Once all of the transfers and preparations are completed, the hospital will re-open as a specialised COVID-19 hospital although the date is not yet fixed. 

On May 1, 2020 Osaka City announced that it had completed the transfer and discharge of patients at Osaka City Jūsō Hospital. 

Following the transfer of all patients, on May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases. UPDATE: On May 1, 2020, Osaka City announced that it had completed the transfer and discharge of patients at Osaka City Jūsō Hospital. Then on May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised covid-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of covid-19 cases.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 24, 2020, at the 31st Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "deliver 15 million [surgical masks throughout the country] within this month. Regarding medical gowns and other equipment, [Japan has] started delivery to prefectures, especially those with a significant number of patients. [The Government] also intend[s] to distribute 1.5 million high performance masks, such as N95 masks, 1.3 million medical gowns, and 1.9 million face shields nationwide, delivering them expeditiously to medical institutions facing shortages of such supplies."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, 2020, at the 31st Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "deliver 15 million [surgical masks throughout the country] within this month. Regarding medical gowns and other equipment, [Japan has] started delivery to prefectures, especially those with a significant number of patients. [The Government] also intend[s] to distribute 1.5 million high performance masks, such as N95 masks, 1.3 million medical gowns, and 1.9 million face shields nationwide, delivering them expeditiously to medical institutions facing shortages of such supplies."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) asks "providers of ... services [for the elderly] to try to keep their facilities open as much as possible" as "[m]ore day care and short-stay facilities for the elderly have shut as the government expanded the state of emergency over the coronavirus crisis nationwide April 16."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) KATŌ Katsunobu announced that MHLW "has begun checking the performance of several test kits that could be used to see the existence of coronavirus antibodies in blood samples." The Minister stated that "the ministry began the evaluation to pave the way for a quick implementation of antibody testing in Japan."

The evaluation is being conducted by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development, with blood samples donated to the Japanese Red Cross Society.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre were extended (weekdays between 08:30 and 21:00, weekend hours from 10:00 to 16:00). 
   
From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. From Monday to Saturday, the Centre will be open for 24 hours and then the Centre will be closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 1, 2020, Osaka Prefecture Governor Hirofumi Yoshimura announced that the private hospital Hanwa Daini Hospital will be assigned as a specialised COVID-19 hospital, making it the second hospital in Osaka Prefecture designated specifically to accept COVID-19 patients. The Hanwa Daini Hospital will accept elderly persons who are considered at high risk of becoming severely ill due to COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 1, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) updated the COVID-19 specific page on its mental health portal “Kokoronomimi” and added “Advice from an Expert.” In this column, an expert encourages thinking about the roots of everyday anxieties and worries as various aspects of one’s life are impacted by COVID-19.

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). description: On May 4, 2020, the Embassy of Japan in Pakistan announced that “to better equip the medical staff fighting the COVID-19 as a frontline force,” “an international Japanese NGO, KnK (Kokkyo naki Kodomotachi, Children without Borders)” “provided Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) and other necessary medical equipment through a local Pakistani NGO Friends Welfare Association to three hospitals where corona virus patients are being treated.” “MATSUDA Kuninori, Ambassador of Japan to Pakistan has said that all of this emergency support is funded by personal donations from the people of Japan for the people of Pakistan.”

description: On May 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) “approved remdesivir as the first treatment for COVID-19 in Japan, three days after the Japanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Gilead Sciences Inc. submitted the application. The process was accelerated under a special exception clause for pharmaceuticals that are approved by another nation with comparable standards as Japan’s.” “The health ministry will initially manage the supply and distribute remdesivir to hospitals with patients with severe symptoms. The drug will be provided for free at first.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 7, 2020 the Japanese government presented a shipment of Avigan (favipiravir) to the Estonian Embassy in Japan. This shipment will arrive in Estonia next week. Avigan will be used in Estonia in clinical trials to assess its possibility as a treatment for COVID-19. “Japan issued the medicine for free for human trials in the framework of international cooperation, and Estonia is obligated to share the results of its clinical research with Japan.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 8, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that it has "opened a telephone consultation center to support local medical workers and their families" relieve their mental burdens.
type_text: Mental health hotline to support local medical workers who may be experiencing stress due to increased workloads as well as harassment and abuse.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 9, 2020, it was announced that a "group of researchers at the University of Tokyo has started clinical trials of [...] [n]afamostat mesylate, [...] marketed under the brand name Futhan. The tests are being conducted on 160 patients with pneumonia stemming from the coronavirus at the University of Tokyo Hospital and five other medical facilities in Japan. The patients are divided into two groups. One group is administered Futhan and anti-flu drug Avigan. The other is given only Avigan. University of Tokyo Professor Inoue Junichiro is involved in the trials."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 9, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (Japan) has "released a stockpile of data on the number of coronavirus tests conducted and the infection rate dating back to late January. Disjointed data on testing, not just in Tokyo but throughout Japan, has been the subject of controversy and scrutiny for months. Researchers say it’s impossible to understand the true severity of the pandemic without this information."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
On April 30, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced that from May 11, 2020 the Health Center Real-time Information-sharing System on COVID-19 (HER-SYS) will be implemented in some public health centres. Following, the preliminary implementation, the system will be introduced country-wide on May 17, 2020

With this new digital system, doctors, hospitals and local public health centres can promptly share information on patients infected with covid-19 with relevant prefectural and national government departments. This will allow for smoother organisation of counter-cluster measures and the coordination of hospitalisations. Infected patients can also easily report changes in their health condition with the HER-SYS and can monitor their condition.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Due to the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, it is becoming difficult to obtain masks at stores. The Tottori prefecture (Japan), in cooperation with supermarkets etc., will arrange the purchase.
Mask purchase tickets will be distributed to all units in the prefecture between May 14th, 2020 (May 13th at some post offices) and 20th.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to ‘v) Securing the supply of medical goods’ it was decided that ‘A secure manufacturing system will be set up for medical supplies, medical equipment, and medical materials to provide them promptly and smoothly to medical institutions that need them.’ It specified that ‘In particular, the securing of supplies of personal protective equipment, such as masks for medical institutions that conduct PCR tests and admit patients, will be prioritized.’
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 14, 2020, at the 34th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister ABE Shinzō asked that “we will cover, with the government outlays, the total expenditure of the comprehensive support subsidy for medical systems and increase the amount significantly. By doing so, we intend to extend robust support, such as enhancing screening structures and care for the patients with severe symptoms in order to solve various issues faced by medical institutions”.

description: On May 1st, 2020, Kanagawa prefecture (Japan) announced it will collaborate with the Prefectural Hospital Organization and Shonan Kamakura General Hospital "to set up a “Medical Center for Psychiatric Corona Priority Medical Institution", which will start accepting infected patients with severe mental illness from mid May.

description: On 18 May 2020, Nara Prefecture requested business operators and citizens of the prefecture to donate medical supplies. Those who have other medical equipment should first call the Nara Coronavirus Material Procurement and Distribution Group.

description: From June 2019, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) has established a “ONE STOP” type of consultation desk in Shimane International Center to respond to various information and consultation regarding to the daily lives of foreign residents. description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). With regards to “8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures,” it has been decided that “ii) Experts will be secured and trained to conduct the counter-cluster measures and strengthen the health center system. Technologies such as apps and social networking systems will also be utilized to promptly introduce a system for efficiently controlling infections and quickly grasping the infection situation.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Included in the document is consideration that “i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms” and it was decided that “Asymptomatic pathogen carriers and patients with mild symptoms who do not require hospitalization will recuperate at lodging facilities, etc.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) "started a measure for supporting seven R&D projects [...] which are highly urgent and that must be tackled quickly, as part of the efforts undertaken in the Project for Developing Technologies for Addressing the Novel Coronavirus Disease and Other Infectious Diseases under the FY2020 Supplementary Budget established on April 30, 2020." One of the R&D projects, represented by the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), pertains to the "development of a highly-reliable, rapid diagnosis system for detecting the novel coronavirus disease."

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The document states that “ii) An outpatient and testing system will be secured for suspected COVID-19 patients” that would “Designate medical institutions to treat people who may develop severe symptoms as medical institutions that do not provide COVID-19 outpatient services, in principle.”

Medical institutions where persons may be more at risk of developing severe symptoms include cancer centres, dialysis medical institutions, obstetric care institutions and such.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases. Existing patients were transferred to different hospitals to prepare for the acceptance of COVID-19 patients who require hospitalisation, but experience mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Increased hygiene measures were also implemented, such as covering carpet with an antibacterial vinyl sheet to make it easier to wipe.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases. Existing patients were transferred to different hospitals to prepare for the acceptance of COVID-19 patients who require hospitalisation, but experience mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Increased hygiene measures were also implemented, such as covering carpet with an antibacterial vinyl sheet to make it easier to wipe. 

On July 27, 2020, Osaka City Jūsō Hospital resumed outpatient treatment. All medical treatments and procedures will resume, excluding obstetrics. 
 UPDATE: The original policy did not have an end date. On July 27, 2020, Osaka City Juso Hospital resumed normal activities, excluding obstetrics.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “examine and evaluate the division of functions between PCR tests and antigen tests and implement more tests including PCR not only for medical personnel but also for other close contacts.”

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Included in the document is consideration that “i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms” and it was decided that “Asymptomatic pathogen carriers and patients with mild symptoms who do not require hospitalization will recuperate at lodging facilities, etc.” “Temporary lodging facilities such as hotels will be secured and managed for this purpose.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Included in the document under “4) Medical care, etc” is consideration that “i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms” and it was decided that “To secure hospital beds, roles will be divided among medical institutions in each region, such as by designating preferred medical institutions to gather novel coronavirus patients.”

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). description:
On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). The document states that “ii) An outpatient and testing system will be secured for suspected COVID-19 patients” that would “Designate medical institutions [that]... treat people who may develop severe symptoms as medical institutions that do not provide COVID-19 outpatient services, in principle.”

Medical institutions where persons may be more at risk of developing severe symptoms include cancer centres, dialysis medical institutions, obstetric care institutions and such.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Under “4) Medical care, etc,” with regards to “iv) Securing medical workers” it was decided that “Measures will be promoted to prevent temporary leave/leaving of jobs by medical workers, return of potential qualified personnel to the workforce, reallocation of human resources in the medical field, etc.”

description: On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Under “4) Medical care, etc,” with regards to “v) Securing the supply of medical goods” it was decided that “A secure manufacturing system will be set up for medical supplies, medical equipment, and medical materials to provide them promptly and smoothly to medical institutions that need them. In particular, the securing of supplies of personal protective equipment, such as masks for medical institutions that conduct PCR tests and admit patients, will be prioritized.”

description: On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: If a person enrolled in the National Health Insurance System is infected with the new coronavirus (including cases where there is a symptom such as fever and infection is suspected), he/she will be able to pay the injury/illness allowance for the period during which he/she cannot receive labor for medical treatment, as announced by the Okayama prefecture (Japan) on May 27.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

"This Grant Aid project provides medical equipment worth 2 billion Japanese yen (approximately 18.1 million USD) in total, such as radiography system, intensive care unit beds and medical monitors, to hospitals and laboratories in Myanmar." "The first flight carrying medical equipment [...] arrived at Yangon International Airport on 15 August 2020."

description: On June 8, 2020, the Ambassador of Japan to the Philippines HANEDA Koji signed a P944-million (2-billion-yen) grant to the Philippines. "According to the Japan embassy, the grant will support the Department of Health (DOH) through the provision of "state-of-the-art medical equipment" such as CT scanners, X-ray machines, MRI systems, and hemodialysis machines, among others, which will be installed in key hospitals. Laboratory surveillance sites will also be set up across the country."

description: On June 8, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced the establishment of a web survey to report health-related materials and supplies "that are expected to run out of stock within a week" at hospitals, clinics and medical institutions that treat COVID-19 patients or collect samples for PCR tests. The web survey will be used as a tool for the government to contact the concerned medical institutions and urgently distribute the requested medical supplies.

description: On April 1, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan ABE Shinzō announced that the Government of Japan will distribute two reusable/washable cloth face masks to each registered household, prioritising the regions with most coronavirus infections. This policy is part of a wider economic package that will be published after April 6. The distribution will be carried out at the end of April 2020. UPDATE: At a press conference on June 25, 2020, the Chief Cabinet Secretary of Japan SUGA Yoshihide announced that the distribution of masks was completed on June 20, 2020.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
As published on July 8, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) has suspended group examinations due to worries about the spread of the coronavirus, switching instead to individual medical checkups of infants and toddlers. Checkpoints will proceed until the end of July. 

"The shift is aimed at preparing health care workers and the wider medical system for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On June 15, 2020, the Minister of Finance of Japan (MOF) "added medical fields to the list of domestic industrial sectors subject to foreign investment restrictions to maintain domestic control over cutting-edge technologies including those related to dealing with the coronavirus pandemic." "The tighter controls on pharmaceutical products and advanced medical equipment under the foreign exchange and foreign trade law will take effect" on July 15, 2020. Already on April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 17, 2020, it was reported that on July 16, 2020 "the Ambassador of Japan to Bangladesh, and Ms. Fatima Yasmin, Secretary, Economic Relations Division, Ministry of Finance, signed the Exchange of Notes on Japanese Grant aid "Economic and Social Development Programme"(JPY 1.0 billion, about USD 10 million) representing the respective governments." Through the agreement, the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) will send medical equipment to Bangladesh. "The medical equipment (i.e., CT Scanner, X-ray Machine) provided through this grant aid is expected to strengthen the health system of hospitals, in particular, ICUs treating COVID-19 patients in Bangladesh."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) is implementing hospitalization measures and expanding its inspection measures to prepare for a second wave of the coronavirus. 

"We will work to increase the number of cooperating medical institutions such as clinics that collect samples.

Disseminate saliva collection that can reduce the risk and burden of specimen collection at cooperating medical institutions. To that end, we will work to establish a test system that can smoothly collect and transport samples and increase the number of samples.

Until the testing by saliva collection is available at the cooperating medical institutions, we will expand the induction of PCR tests for those returning to the home or contact of those who are considered to need testing among those who have undergone medical examination."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "the government is preparing to send hospital and public health nurses to Okinawa Prefecture." "Nurses will be sent from other prefectures as a further spread of infections is expected to strain the island prefecture’s health care system in terms of hospital beds and personnel." On August 16, 2020, Okinawa Governor Denny Tamaki "asked for such assistance at a meeting with state minister of health Gaku Hashimoto. The central government will work with the National Governors’ Association so that about 10 hospital nurses will be dispatched within a week. The number will be raised to about 50 eventually. [...] The health ministry will also consider sending to Okinawa medical workers who can handle extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, life support systems and taking COVID-19 patients to hospitals outside the prefecture."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 11, 2020, in the framework of the "Cabinet Order for the Partial Revision of the Order for Enforcement of the Act on Emergency Measures for Stabilizing Living Conditions of the Public", Japan promulgated that, from March 15, 2020, "it is prohibited to [i] resell face masks that you have bought at retail stores, online shopping malls or other businesses [ii] to unspecified persons or a large number of people online or through stores or other businesses [iii] at prices higher than the acquisition prices." UPDATE: On August 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the prohibition to resell face masks will be lifted on August 29, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption." UPDATE: On August 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the prohibition to resell disinfectant will be lifted on August 29, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 26, 2020, it was agreed that Japan would provide "US$ 3.8 million for medical and hospital equipment to support Zimbabwe’s COVID-19 response." The Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) will provide to the Ministry of Health and Child Care of Zimbabwe "digital X-ray systems, bedside monitors, defibrillators, electrocardiograms, blood gas analysers, laryngoscopes, and suction units, as well as hospital beds, emergency carts, autoclaves, wheelchairs and IV stands," among other equipment. "It will be installed at 4 central and 8 provincial hospitals." "It is expected that these two grants for essential equipment will enable the recipient hospitals to have increased capacities to treat patients with COVID-19 as well as other conditions."

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to establish an infectious disease response center to monitor the health conditions of athletes participating in the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games in the summer of 2021. The agreement was struck at a meeting of a coordination council over the novel coronavirus epidemic among the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games." "The infectious disease response center, to be set up as part of the organizing committee, will check the health of Olympians and Paralympians throughout the sporting events. If athletes test positive for the novel coronavirus, the center will share necessary information with their national delegations and related sports organizations."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to set up a hub serving as a public health center and a fever clinic for outpatients. The council[, composed by the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games,] will start work on details, including securing staff personnel for the new bases." "The hub serving as a public health center is likely to be established in or near the athlete village, which will be used by up to some 30,000 people. If athletes or other people linked to the Tokyo Games are confirmed with the virus, the hub will conduct active epidemiological surveys in coordination with the infectious disease center and identify those who had close contact with the infected individuals."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 22, 2020, it was announced that a "coronavirus testing center will open next month at Narita airport near Tokyo, enabling departing travelers to obtain a certificate for a negative test result within two hours." description: On December 4, 2020, it was announced that the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has commissioned a research group led by Kanazawa Medical University Professor Miwa Takaki to "conduct a large-scale survey on the loss of smell as a symptom of COVID-19." "The survey, which will begin later this month, will monitor the patients' olfactory functions using test kits. The group will also look at stress and other mental conditions when people suffer from the symptom for a long time." The results will be analysed by the end of March 2021.

description: On December 10, 2020, NHK announced that the Ministry of Defense of Japan "plans to dispatch Self-Defense Force medical personnel to Osaka Prefecture." "The ministry will likely send a total of about seven personnel consisting of nurses and other staff. They are expected to be assigned to an existing medical emergency center as well as a facility exclusively for patients with severe COVID-19 symptoms that will open on Tuesday." "The dispatch will likely continue for roughly two weeks. The ministry is expected to decide on the dispatch on Friday after receiving an official request from Osaka Prefecture."

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on November 27, 2020 that it is seeking 3,000 volunteers to take "free antibody tests" to "estimate the rate of those who have been infected" with COVID-19 in the past. Tests will be conducted between December 16 and 24, 2020. Volunteers are limited to those who are 20+ years old and are from Kitakyushu, Fukuoka, Chikugo or Chikuho.

description: On December 28, 2020, it was announced that "travelers arriving from overseas amid the COVID-19 pandemic can now catch a train to downtown Tokyo from Narita Airport in train cars reserved specifically for them, on a major train line operated by Keisei Electric Railway Co." "The Keisei Skyliner started a service [...] that will see it make 15 trips a day from the airport in Chiba Prefecture to Tokyo’s Ueno Station with the front cars of each train reserved for such travelers, the company said. The cars are disinfected after each run, while adjacent cars are kept empty."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On December 28, 2020, at the 50th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Japan’s Prime Minister SUGA Yoshihide announced that “we will ensure that medical services are available during the New Year’s holiday period. The number of health professionals on duty is unavoidably reduced over the holidays. We will, however, make consultation centers being operated at local public health centers, and certain other facilities, able to provide services around the clock even over the New Year’s holidays, so that necessary tests and treatments are provided to those needing them. We are collaborating with local doctors’ associations and other groups and have secured a structure for treatment through night and holiday clinics and by opening medical institutions on a rotating basis, while also ensuring a certain level of screening at private testing institutions to be provided”.

description: On January 19, 2021, Osaka Prefecture (Japan) "asked private hospitals in the western Japan prefecture [...] to offer around 30 beds to treat novel coronavirus patients. description: Since January 31, 2021, Japan's Ground Self-Defense Forces (GSDF) "have begun providing medical support for people" in Miyakojima City, Okinawa Prefecture. "Miyakojima City, with a population of about 55,000, reported more than 110 cases during the five-day period through Saturday. With the city's health care system under pressure, Okinawa Prefecture requested the deployment of GSDF nurses to the city. Five nurses arrived at a nursing care facility in the city on Sunday."

description: Beginning on February 1, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) "will lend pulse oximeters to people receiving new coronavirus treatment at home. The medical device calculates oxygen levels in the blood just by slipping it on a finger. The prefecture recently recorded its first death of a home-treatment patient and hopes this technology will prevent more occurrences by signaling patients to report to local health offices after experiencing a decline in the oxygen level."

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, in addition to efforts until now, the efforts of municipal health centres will be assisted by applied use of IHEAT, the horizontal expansion of good examples of securing personnel and the applied use of outsourcing health centre business including in responding to the hospitalization of infected persons and health inspections of people recuperating at home. In addition, information related to mutant strains has been added to HER-SYS and, based on this and in addition to rapidly striving towards information sharing between national and local government, the thorough and applied use of functions like health follow-ups will be aimed for. Regarding health centres in core cities, strengthened support for expert dispatch systems in the event that infection clusters arise will also proceed.

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."

description: From February 16, 2020 onwards, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will carry out PCR tests sequentially for those under the age of 70 onboard the Diamond Princess cruise ship. Up until now, tests have been prioritised for the elderly over 70 and those who have in the same room as a person who has tested positive.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus."

On February 18, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced a policy and provisionary budget for the expansion of its testing system for COVID-19, from a capacity of 120 cases to 240 cases a day at the Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Public Health.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to “(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan,” it was agreed to “A) a) Identify suspected patients based on notification from physicians based on the Infectious Diseases Control Law, and conduct PCR tests when the physician deems necessary [and] identify close contacts of confirmed patients through active epidemiology surveys, in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law."

description: On May 8, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) “released revised guidelines on when to consult authorities over suspected coronavirus infection, removing the body temperature threshold from the old guidelines.""Under the new guidelines, anyone with a high fever, breathing difficulties or who is feeling lethargic is encouraged to immediately phone the relevant local public health office to inquire about a PCR test. Likewise, those vulnerable to serious symptoms of COVID-19, such as senior citizens or those with pre-existing health conditions, can now call even if they only experience minor cold-like symptoms."

On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus." UPDATE: On May 8, 2020 the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) revised the guidelines on coronavirus consultations, which stated who should contact authorities for a PCR test. The 37.5 degrees celsius fever rule has been removed. "Under the new guidelines, anyone with a high fever, breathing difficulties or who is feeling lethargic is encouraged to immediately phone the relevant local public health office to inquire about a PCR test. Likewise, those vulnerable to serious symptoms of COVID-19, such as senior citizens or those with pre-existing health conditions, can now call even if they only experience minor cold-like symptoms."

On May 8, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) announced that MOD plans on May 10, 2020 "to conduct tests for the crew members of the MSDF destroyer Kirisame, which is scheduled to leave the Sasebo base in Nagasaki Prefecture, southwestern Japan, [...] on a mission to gather intelligence for securing sea lane safety in the Middle East." The Minister of Defense KŌNO Tarō "said that the Kirisame's crew will have coronavirus tests after departure, and that the vessel will head for the Middle East after conducting training in home waters for 14 days, if all crew members are test negative for the virus."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 13, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government "began a study into whether sewage samples can be used to detect signs of a spread of novel coronavirus infections. To prepare for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections, the metropolitan government aims to establish a method to analyze sewage for the virus in cooperation with the Japan Society on Water Environment." "The metropolitan government will collect 300 milliliters of treated and untreated sewage samples once a week at 15 sewage treatment plants in the nation’s capital."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On May 15, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu announced that the Ministry "will conduct COVID-19 antibody testing for about 10,000 people as early as next month. The testing will cover several prefectures, including those with many coronavirus cases and those with a few cases. The ministry plans to find out whether people have antibodies against the new coronavirus and the amount of antibodies a person has."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu announced that the Government of Japan"will conduct testing for coronavirus antibodies in Tokyo and two other prefectures, starting early next month for about 10,000 people." "The test will cover Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture, where the number of coronavirus cases per 100,000 people is relatively large, and Miyagi Prefecture, which has fewer cases."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Tokyo Prefecture; Osaka Prefecture; Miyagi Prefecture

description: On June 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "it has approved the use of saliva samples in polymerase chain reaction tests for the novel coronavirus. Saliva use is available within nine days after people start developing symptoms of COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by the coronavirus. [...] The new method is less risky as saliva samples are enclosed in special containers by patients themselves," thus reducing the "infection risks to medical workers."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Due to a new confirmed case of COVID-19 on July 2 in Tottori City, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) is conducting PCR tests on its citizens, as announced on July 14.  

"We are actively conducting PCR testing; if you are concerned about possible infection, please first contact the Shimane International Center’s “One Stop Center” Consultation hotline for foreign residents."

description: On July 15, 2020, the Okinawa Chubu Central Hospital (Okinawa, Japan) "started collecting specimens for antibody surveys to be carried out by the Okinawa Prefectural Government in partnership with the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) for a survey of the state of coronavirus infection in Okinawa. [...] The same will be carried out at the Public Kumejima Hospital. Collection of antibodies will start at prefectural hospitals in the northern and southern parts of Okinawa Island, Miyako, and Yaeyama as soon as approval is received from the ethics review committee."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 17, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) KATŌ Katsunobu announced that the ministry "will allow the use of saliva samples from asymptomatic people in polymerase chain reaction and antigen testing for the novel coronavirus." "The government conducted an experiment in which asymptomatic patients had mucus samples taken for PCR tests, as well as saliva samples for PCR and antigen tests. It found that the accuracy of the tests did not differ greatly."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

This test will be used along with the PCR test and bring the Prefecture's daily COVID-19 testing capacity to up to 2,450 tests per day.

In order to strengthen border measures, the TACO system at Naha Airport will be enhanced by opening up the possibility of antigen testing.

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “will make all possible efforts to secure screening capacity for over 10,000 people at Narita Airport, Haneda Airport and Kansai International Airport by next month, and further advance the preparation of the necessary screening structures at other airports as well.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As announced on September 28, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) will be carrying out prenatal coronavirus tests to relieve the anxiety of pregnant women from Thursday, October 1st.

description: On October 6, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Defense (MOD) announced that that 28 Ground Self-Defense Force (GSDF) members became infected with COVID-19 during training held at Asaka Military Base. The GSDF subsequently carried out testing on a number of GSDF personnel who may have come into contact with the infected in order to determine the scale of the outbreak.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: It is announced on October 29, 2020, that Fukuoka City is introducing a "PCR-test van to brace for anticipated COVID-19 clusters at residential care facilities and other places in remote areas".
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On November 12, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) TAMURA Norihisa announced that "anyone with a high fever in Japan can now get tested for the novel coronavirus and seasonal influenza at 24,629 facilities nationwide." "Anticipating a simultaneous outbreak of COVID-19 and seasonal influenza in the winter season, the ministry had asked local governments to designate facilities that can handle medical examinations and testing by the end of October."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 21, 2020, at the 47th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Japan’s Prime Minister SUGA Yoshihide announced that “In order to protect the lives of the people by preventing patients from developing severe symptoms, when a patient tests positive at medical or day-care facilities, we will immediately screen all the patients, residents, and employees of those facilities, with the government bearing the costs”.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 27, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) TAMURA Norihisa announced that the government "plans a second round of antibody testing for past infections of the novel coronavirus in five heavily populated areas." "Approximately 15,000 tests will be conducted by year-end" in the prefectures of Aichi and Fukuoka in addition to Tokyo, Osaka, and Miyagi, object of the 1st round of antibody testing conducted in June. "It plans to test 3,000 people in each prefecture for residents aged 20 or older, who will be chosen at random."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On November 10, 2020, Fukuoka City announces that ahead of influenza season, it will accelerate PCR testing for "local medical and elderly care workers". The City is doing this by seeking a "special operator" who will "provide up to 2,500 virus screenings and handle related jobs" through a budget of 700 million yen.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On January 7, 2021, the Japan Sumo Association (JSA), a body under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT), "has decided to have all its members, including wrestlers and stablemasters, tested for coronavirus infection. The association's public affairs director, Shibatayama, announced" on January 7, 2021 "that all members will take PCR tests before the New Year tournament begins" on January 10, 2020. "All results should be known" on January 8, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 6, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) "began random screenings for the new coronavirus. Special counters were set up near important train stations and shopping districts to distribute free PCR-test kits. People without COVID-19 like symptoms can register at the counters and mail their swabs to designated laboratories. The program is run in collaboration with the national government."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “PCR tests in facilities for the elderly,” Fukuoka Prefecture encourages “administrators of facilities for the elderly and facilities for the disabled to utilise the PCR tests conducted by the prefectural government and encourage staff to be tested.” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, immigrants from countries where mutant strains are endemic are required to  1) wait at a designated facility for 3 days after entering the country, 2) conduct additional tests on the 3rd day after entering the country, 3) have the health condition checked for 14 days after entering the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, since February 2021 efforts to create and implement a scheme for the focused testing of old people’s home employees in high infection areas in the 10 prefectures where States of Emergency have been proceeding, with the aim of implementing the scheme by the end of March. Besides steadily implementing tests based on the plan, good examples of these efforts will also be demonstrated.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, large cities with entertainment districts which are part of the 10 prefectures where State of Emergency measures were announced will, responding to the infection situation in other municipalities and regions, implement tests based on the new intensive implementation plan from April to June.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that mutant strains will be detected at an early stage and clusters will be contained quickly through active epidemiological investigations and tests to prevent the spread of mutant strains throughout the society.

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that from the perspective of strengthening the nationwide monitoring system, the sampling rate in screening tests of mutant strains will be increased to 40% at an early stage, people infected with the mutant strain will be actively confirmed and a wide inspection will be carried out around the places of the infected people. In the future, the number of tests of autonomous bodies will be periodically monitored.

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that extensive PCR testing centred on shopping and entertainment districts and focusing on asymptomatic people will be carried out. This data will be analysed with other test data and data such as SNS information in order to infer signs of infection spread. These monitoring tests will begin from March 22, 2021 and it is hypothesised that 10,000 tests will be carried out per day at the airports, train stations, universities and shopping/entertainment districts of regions where the state of emergency is lifted.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Government and local governments “will encourage restaurants to take necessary infection control measures to prevent places where the "3Cs" (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings) overlap.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 27, 2020, the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ) announced that it will "provide subsidies to help restaurants introduce high-performance ventilation systems to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus." "The subsidies will be paid to cover half to two-thirds of costs to install such advanced ventilation systems, which each costs about 500,000 yen. The ministry expects that the aid will cover a total of some 3,000 ventilation systems at 800 to 1,000 locations across the nation."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). description: "The prefectural government of Yamagata started on Saturday [(April 18, 2020)] body temperature checks near the prefectural borders, including at expressway rest areas, major train stations and airports, in a bid to prevent a further spread of the new coronavirus. The thermal checks, targeting visitors to the northeastern Japan prefecture, will be conducted through May 10," 2020. UPDATE: New information: extended until May 10, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Kagoshima Prefecture requested travellers to refrain coming to Kagoshima Prefecture for "travel/recreation" during Golden Week (May 2-6).

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips." UPDATE: On May 14, this policy was updated to have an unspecified end date.
 UPDATE: Though the policy was previously slated to end on May 14, the May 14 office communication extended this policy to an unspecified end date.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As part of Ishikawa prefecture's measures of the state of emergency, Ishikawa prefecture requested citizens not to visit or travel to other prefectures on April 16. This request will be maintained from April 16 to May 6. As Ishikawa prefectural state of emergency extended on May 4, the end of the request for refraining to travel across prefectures has been extended from May 6 to May 31. UPDATE: As Ishikawa prefectural state of emergency extended on May 4, the end of the request for refraining to travel across prefectures has been extended from May 6 to May 31.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 13, 2020, the Government of Japan issued a request to "citizens not to travel between areas where its coronavirus state of emergency is in place and others once the measure is partially lifted." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi "made the comments after the association proposed that the government ask citizens not to travel across prefectural borders even after the state of emergency is partially lifted."

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate ‘6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures’ it was decided that ‘i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as ‘Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk.’
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 1) self-restraint in going out, it was decided that they should encourage people to avoid non-essential travel to or returning from prefectures with a relatively higher risk, including the Prefectures under Special Caution (Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Osaka and Hyogo).

UPDATE: The policy is targeted towards all regions in Hokkaido, more restrictions like distance between people and no visits to restaurants and bars, as well as timing set.

Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips.”

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can “Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk. Avoid going to places with ‘3Cs’.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to 2) self-restraint in going out, etc it was statedthat from June 1 until June 18, prefectures will be encouraged to carefully consider non-essential and non-urgent travel among the 5 prefectures of Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa, as well as between those 5 prefectures and other prefectures.
