description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips.”
UPDATE: The policy was updated to cover the period June 1 to June 18. UPDATE: The original policy was set to end on May 25, but the May 25 document "Prefectural response during the transition" updated the policy so that travel between the 5 prefectures (Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa) would be extended to the period between June 1 to June 18.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) has been declared off-limits to those living and working at MCAS Iwakuni due to an increase in coronavirus cases in the city.

"The ban took effect on July 21 and applies to all personnel, including service members, Defense Department civilian employees and family members, looking to travel to Hiroshima in their spare time, according to a post Monday on the air station’s official Facebook page."

description: On August 6, 2020, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki, jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, asked residents to "restrain their behavior during the annual Bon holidays and refrain from traveling across prefectural borders if not urgent or necessary." "At the same time, Omura [Aichi's Governor] told reporters after the meeting that he will allow residents to travel to the neighboring prefectures of Gifu and Mie because those three prefectures in the Tokai region, including Aichi, share the same economic zone."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 6, 2020, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki declared a second prefectural-level state of emergency regarding COVID-19. In this framework, Aichi Prefecture requested the residents in Aichi “not to travel or go out, especially if they do not feel well.” The request will take effect from August 6, 2020 to August 24, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 16, 2021, the Governor of Nagasaki (Japan), NAKAMURA Hōdō issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus for the city of Nagasaki from January 16, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this regard, the Governor asked residents to refrain from travelling to and from remote islands unless truly unavoidable from January 18, 2021 until February 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 6, 2020, at the Sixth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that Japan will deny entry to foreigners who were on the cruise ship MS Westerdam, departed from Hong Kong, from February 7, 2020, unless there are special circumstances.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed that, B) a) In communities where the number of patients continues to increase; [to] switch to broader calls for refraining from going out, while reducing the scale of active epidemiology surveys and health observations on close contacts [and to] continue and strengthen the responses to clusters of patients, depending on the situation in the community.”

Oita Prefecture requested on April 1 for residents to "avoid outings" "unless it is essential" from April 4. The Prefecture also noted that "younger individuals, who often do not exhibit symptoms, should exercise extra caution".

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will at first request a self-restraint of going out while indicating the period and area as necessary. Examples of outing that are not covered by such request would include activities necessary for maintaining daily life such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to work as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk.”

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (1) Prefectures under Special Caution (Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Osaka and Hyogo) as part of 1) self-restraint in going out, it was decided that, continuing policy outlined in the May 4 document “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”, these prefectures will aim for a 70-80% reduction in interpersonal contact opportunities and continue to call for self-restraint in going out.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “The Prefectures under Specific Cautions [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, and Kanagawa], in particular, will request cooperation in refraining from leaving home to ‘reduce the contact among people by 70% at minimum or 80% ideally’  (Activities necessary for maintaining daily life and health, such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to workplaces as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk, are excluded.)”
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On June 18, 2020, at the 38th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Japan’s Prime Minister ABE Shinzō announced that “the restrictions on travel beyond prefectural borders will be removed, including those with some parts of the Tokyo Metropolitan Area as well as Hokkaido. Concerts and other events can be held if they are kept under a certain number of people or percentage of capacity. Furthermore, the requests for the temporary closure of businesses in certain industries, such as dining venues with staff who entertain guests, will also be lifted, provided that those business operators will adhere to the relevant guidelines”.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced that restrictions on nonessential outings for Kitakyushu City will be lifted on June 19, 2020. UPDATE: Policy did not have end date, but now does

As part of (1) promoting a change in behaviour suitable for the “New Everyday” within 2) Efforts to encourage restaurant users adopt behaviour to protect themselves it was decided that people will be encouraged to thoroughly avoid places where the 3Cs emerge.

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) strengthening efforts at infection prevention together with economic organizations within 3) Infection prevention measures at workplaces and universities, etc it was decided that each business will be encouraged to avoid large get-togethers and dinner parties after work.

description: On July 31, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, asked residents of Okinawa's Main Island to refrain from nonessential and nonurgent outings and residents of other areas to refrain from going out as much as possible.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its own declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked residents of all areas of Okinawa to refrain from nonessential and nonurgent outings, to shop alone, to avoid going out to places where a large number of people gather, and to avoid going downtown.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 04/08/2020 Kumamoto Prefecture moved its coronavirus alertness level from 3 to 4. As a consequence of this, prefectural authorities demanded strongly that citizens do not travel out of the prefecture, and avoid any non-urgent and non-essential outings.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 2020-08-05, Japan’s Subcommittee on Novel Coronavirus Infection Countermeasures published “Regarding returning home for the Bon holidays”. As part of this document, it was requested that people avoid situations where the risk of infection is high such as dining together in large groups and to take care to prevent old people becoming infected.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 5, 2020, Japan’s Subcommittee on Novel Coronavirus Infection Countermeasures published “Regarding returning home for the Bon holidays.” As part of this document, it was stated that where it is judged as difficult for the above response to the taken, people will be urged to carefully consider alternatives like online communication until infections subside. In the first place, people experiencing symptoms of a fever, etc are requested to refrain from returning home. People who have recently been to high-risk areas are also requested to make careful considerations
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 6, 2020, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki declared a second prefectural-level state of emergency regarding COVID-19. In this framework, Aichi Prefecture requested residents to “avoid going outside unless it is necessary or urgent.” The request will take effect from August 6, 2020, to August 24, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 21, 2020, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki stated that “the Prefectural State of Emergency declared on August 6, 2020 has ended on August 24, 2020,” however, “this does not mean that risks are gone.” Accordingly, Aichi Prefecture requested residents to “avoid going outside unless it is necessary or urgent.” The request will take effect from August 24, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On December 31, 2020, Prime Minister SUGA Yoshihide called "people in Tokyo and elsewhere not to go out for nonessential purposes."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 6, 2021, the Governor of Nagasaki (Japan), NAKAMURA Hōdō issued a prefectural-level special warning, requesting residents to refrain from going out for non-essential and non-urgent reasons in Nagasaki City (except for visiting medical institutions, shopping for daily necessities such as food and clothing, commuting to work or school, or doing outdoor exercise and walking) from January 7, 2021 until January 17, 2021.

description: On January 12, 2021, the Governor of Fukushima (Japan), UCHIBORI Masao enacted prefectural-level emergency measures due to the novel coronavirus in line with the prefectural assessment to raise the stage of alert of Fukushima to stage 3. In this regard, the Governor asked residents to refrain from leaving their house for non-essential and non-urgent reasons from January 13, 2021 until February 7, 2021.

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting called for "close international cooperation in order to make every possible effort to collect information on the situation of infectious diseases, infectiousness and pathogenicity, etc. from the World Health Organization and from other countries."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters" in order to "comprehensively and strongly promote countermeasures by the government."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 29, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announces the creation of the Fukuoka Prefecture New Coronavirus Infectious Disease Control Headquarters which will be launched on January 30, 2020. The purpose of the Headquarters is to work with prefectural departments to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and provide up-to-date COVID-19 information to residents.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On January 28, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan "designated the infectious disease related to the novel coronavirus a Designated Infectious Disease under the Act on the Prevention of Infectious Diseases and Medical Care for Patients with Infectious Diseases". The enforcement of the designation is planned from February 7, 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation to deny entry into the country to some foreigners in a bid to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 13, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted by a Cabinet Decision and promulgated the “Cabinet Order for Designating Novel Coronavirus Infection as a Type of Infectious Disease Under Article 34 of the Quarantine Act” (Cabinet Order No. 28 of 2020) and the “Cabinet Order Partially Amending the Enforcement Order of the Quarantine Act” (Cabinet Order No. 29 of 2020). These cabinet orders entered into force on the following day, February 14."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers

description: On February 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "attended the first Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting at the Prime Minister’s Office" and called for contributions from "experts who are working on the front line in the respective fields, to give due consideration based on the medical and scientific perspectives, including the characteristics of the virus and other knowledge we have gathered so far", adding that the "Government will introduce further countermeasures in advance, following the advice based on the medical and scientific perspectives proposed by this expert meeting." The Expert Meeting was announced on February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters: "in order to advance deliberations over our countermeasures based on expert knowledge even more than ever before, we will establish an expert meeting under this Headquarters, which consist of infectious disease specialists working on the frontline in their respective fields, and strengthen our responses."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 13, 2020, the Parliament of Japan enacted "a law amendment giving Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the power to declare a state of emergency and take drastic measures in the fight against the spread of the new coronavirus." "The revised law, newly covering the coronavirus, will allow the government to declare a state of emergency to authorize governors of the 47 prefectures to place restrictions on the private rights of citizens." The law will be enforced from March 14, 2020 and "would grant the power for two years."

description: On March 26, 2020, the Government of Japan established "new headquarters on the fight against the new coronavirus, under a special law that was revised recently to boost measures to prevent the spread of the virus. The launch of the new headquarters under the law is one of the procedures needed for allowing the Japanese leader to declare a state of emergency over the coronavirus outbreak. The new body will be headed by the prime minister." "The headquarters will hold its first meeting immediately after Abe's cabinet decides its launch" on the evening of March 26, 2020.

description:
On 6 July 2020, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education established a "talent pool" or "human resources bank" to assemble people who can work in schools at the primary, middle and high school levels as temporary teachers or support staff. Whilst schools are currently closed, many are concerned that COVID-19 will delay children's learning and so, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education will organise supplementary classes once schools reopen and ask those who apply to lead these classes and those without current teaching qualifications will be asked to provide support. Those who successfully register in the human resources bank will be able to address teacher shortages within schools if teachers are infected by COVID-19. In addition to temporary teachers, this human resources bank aims to assemble 550 learning instructors to assist with after-school supplementary classes and 140 school support staff to help with class preparations.

This human resources bank was established separately to the National Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology's human resources bank.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 8 August 2020, the governors of Japan's 47 prefectures conducted a video meeting and compiled a list of "urgent proposals" to the national government in response to COVID-19. The proposals include:
- A request to increase the amount of extraordinary grants for local governments to fund various measures against the coronavirus pandemic. 
- A revision to the special law for combating the coronavirus so that authorities can impose penalties on business operators that fail to cooperate with business-suspension requests by local governments.
- To consider extending the "Go To Travel" campaign so that tourism-related industries and local economies can sufficiently recover. In particular, the areas impacted by torrential rains in July 2020. 
- To provide more PCR test support and resources.
- To increase dissemination of information on COVID-19 to foreign nationals living in Japan through embassies and other means. 
- Strongly request measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 at US military bases. 
- To take action to eliminate prejudice, discriminatory behavior and false rumours

The governors also advise that people reconsider making trips during the Bon summer holiday season around the middle of August amid concern that the movement of people will spread the virus further.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "it will allow foreigners who completed technical training courses to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they are unable to return to their countries due to the coronavirus pandemic. In early September, the agency will start accepting applications for up to one year of employment under the new program, which is intended to rescue former trainees having difficulty finding jobs in Japan at a time when many companies are scaling down their businesses and cutting job openings amid the health crisis. The agency expects applicants to find jobs in agriculture, food and beverage manufacturing and other sectors suffering severe personnel shortages."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 25, 2020, Japan has announced "a new initiative that will share information and enable dialogue between countries as well as non-state actors on realizing a sustainable and resilient recovery from COVID-19. As part of the initiative, Japan has developed an online platform named 'Platform Redesign 2020' detailing information on policies and actions taken by national governments to further climate change and pandemic recovery simultaneously. Furthermore, Japan will host an Online Ministerial Meeting on September 3, 2020 where ministers and high-level officials from United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Parties will exchange their opinions and information on climate and other environmental measures in the context of COVID-19. The Platform for Redesign is led by the Japanese Ministry of the Environment, supported by UNFCC, and managed by the Institute for Global Environmental Strategies (IGES)."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On September 4, 2020, the 1st coordination meeting for COVID-19 countermeasures at the Olympic and Paralympic Games Tokyo 2020 took place. The government panel was established with the task of "formulating steps to counter the coronavirus pandemic at next summer's rescheduled Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics." "The panel, led by Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Kazuhiro Sugita, in cooperation with the Tokyo metropolitan government and the local Olympic organizing committee, is specifically in charge of crafting border control and safety measures." "The conference was also attended by JOC and JPC members, with infectious disease experts joining as advisors."

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, regarding private medical tests, the country will take the quality control manual into consideration and appropriately carry out quality control while establishing partnership medical institutions and connecting them to medical institutions for medical tests. In the event that a positive test result arises, requests for cooperation based on the Revised Infectious Diseases Act will be carried out and steps will be taken so that initiatives that contribute to socioeconomic activity and infection spread prevention are implemented.

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. description: On April 3, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced an "[e]xtension of the period for acceptance of applications in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus disease". The previous extension, issued on March 17, 2020, granted an extension to applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay of "one month from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national". In accordance with the extension on April 3, 2020, "[t]he immigration counters will be accepting applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay from those foreign nationals [...] whose expiration date [...] for their period of stay is due in March, April, May or June for an extended period of three months from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national." "In addition, those who are staying with the status of residence of “Temporary Visitor” have also been included."
type_text: extension of bureaucratic deadlines
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, 2020 the Government of Japan decided to provide a total of US$1 million in emergency grant aid in order to implement support for countries where there are people infected with the novel coronavirus. The emergency grant aid will be channeled through the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) and by doing so, Japan will provide Avigan to countries that wish to receive it. At present, coordination has already been completed to provide Avigan free of charge within a certain limit to 20 countries, and coordination is currently being advanced with about 30 more countries. The 20 countries with which coordination has already commenced include Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Indonesia, Iran, Myanmar, Saudi Arabia and Turkey.
type_text: Japan provides emergency grant aid through the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) and by doing so, Japan will provide Avigan to countries that wish to receive it.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 17, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that the "Japanese government will exceptionally allow foreigners employed in the country as technical trainees or specified skilled workers to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they become jobless due to the coronavirus crisis." From April 20, 2020, foreign workers will be encouraged to switch to industries facing severe labor shortages and the Agency "together with other public entities, will try to match out-of-work foreigners" with these industries.

Eligible persons should apply to the Regional Immigration Bureau or Branch Office that has jurisdiction over their residence for permission to change their status of residence to “Designated Activities (Employment
Permitted)”.

description: On April 23, 2020, the chairman of the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren) Hiroaki NAKANISHI prompted companies “to be flexible in their recruitment activities for students graduating in spring next year amid the coronavirus crisis. He called on firms, for example, to allow such students to start working later than usual if the virus pandemic leads to a delay in their graduation and makes it difficult for them to join the companies on scheduled dates.” A proposal from Keidanren dated on March 30, 2020 offers examples to allow for maximum flexibility, such as  "extending application deadlines, conducting online seminars and screening, and adjusting schedules."

description: On May 10, 2020, the Japan Society for Oriental Medicine announced that it "is set to study whether and how ethical herbal medicines and antipyretics given to novel coronavirus patients for symptomatic treatment have led to worsening in their conditions. The organization asked medical institutions in the country to provide data, including details of the drugs prescribed to patients and suspected patients of the COVID-19 disease from the virus to contain their fevers or coughs, developments of their symptoms in the 14 days since the start of treatment and whether their symptoms worsened or not. The group hopes to collect data on about 1,000 cases and analyze the data using a statistical method."

Concerning the “5) Handling of schools,” it has been decided that “ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the downsizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.

description: On May 27, 2020, about 140 Japanese who were evacuated from Wuhan earlier this year following the outbreak of the new coronavirus" returned to Wuhan on a chartered plane. "The Japanese government appears to have given its tacit approval of the flight, despite having raised its travel advisory for China to Level 3, which means Japanese citizens are advised not to travel there."

target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On July 1, 2020, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries of Japan (MAFF) announced the amendment of the Act on Domestic Animal Infectious Diseases Control, which considerably restricts the import of animal products into Japan from overseas (either luggage or international parcels) and augments the fines for rule-breakers.
type_text: restrictions to the import of animal products
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 17, 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding the responses of prefectures where infections are spreading”. As part of 1) requesting co-operation from businesses in complying with infection prevention guidelines it was stated that, in prefectures where infections are spreading, restaurants with entertainment like bars and clubs and other establishments that serve alcohol will be urged to keep in mind the following point: upon complying with the guidelines, support is being carried out through a subsidy for business continuity (maximum payment of 2 million yen)
type_text: A policy providing financial support to restaurants and other alcohol-serving establishments to help them continue, provided they adhere to infection prevention guidelines
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (3) efforts by shopping districts within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage shopping districts to take the following initiative: regarding the infection prevention measures taken by restaurants, shopping district associations and the Central Federation of Societies of Commerce and Industry will co-ordinate to inform restaurants in order for business continuity support payments to be adopted.
type_text: Policy whereby restaurants will be informed about the availability of and requirements for business continuity support payments
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of 4) Announcing the names of restaurants, etc for the purpose of avoiding infection spread it was decided that in the event that infected persons arise and it is difficult for the means of infection to be traced, the names of restaurants will be announced; the consent of the relevant restaurant(s) will not be necessary for the announcement. Moreover, if it is thought that the cause of the infection was due to improper implementation of infection prevention measures as indicated in the guidelines, words to that effect will be announced.
type_text: a policy regarding publicizing the names of restaurants in the event that infected persons arise and the means of infection is difficult to trace. Restaurants improperly implementing infection prevention measures will have their names publicized.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-08-07 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding indicators and criteria related to the implementation of countermeasures in response to future changes in the infection situation”. As part of (2) reference indicators, etc within 3) indicators and criteria it was decided that in greater metropolitan areas cases of medical transport difficulty will be used as a reference indicator to see the burden on healthcare provision systems, and the days from infection to diagnosis will be used as a reference indicator to look at the monitoring system. Moreover as assistance indicators the number of installed ECMO machines, the number of other installed ventilator machines and the number of new infections among those over 60 years of age will be used for reference.
type_text: A policy that outlines different indicators to gauge the impact on healthcare systems of COVID-19. These indicators include the number of installed ECMO machines and the number of cases of medical transport difficulty.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-08-07 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding indicators and criteria related to the implementation of countermeasures in response to future changes in the infection situation”. As part of (2) reference indicators, etc within 3) indicators and criteria it was decided that regarding comprehensive judgement on indicators of the situation of pressure on hospital beds it is necessary to take the latest infection speed into account and take measures when the speed is quick and meets indicators. On the other hand, during times such as when a continued expansion in infections is not apparent, judgements should not be made based solely on hospital bed occupancy but make a more comprehensive judgement.
type_text: A policy outlining how decisions should be made based on different indicators at different times
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that from September 18, 2020 until January 15, 2021, restaurants can apply for a subsidy to cover expenses for infection prevention measures. This includes expenses for masks, alcohol disinfectants, non-contact thermometers, face shields, rubber gloves, acrylic plates for partitions, transparent vinyl curtain sheets, circulators and air purifiers.
type_text: Economic policy as this is a subsidy for restaurants to buy COVID infection protection equipment
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces an accommodation discount campaign to incentivize tourists to visit the prefecture. Accommodation vouchers will be provided for eligible hotels and ryokans as well as car rental between November 5, 2020 until February 28, 2021 (or as soon as vouchers sell out).
type_text: Economic policy as it is providing subsidies for accommodation
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced that discount vouchers for the "Go To Eat" program will become available on November 9, 2020. They can be used to get discounts until March 31, 2021 "at local eateries with COVID-19 Safety stickers, except for bars with guest services".
type_text: Economic policy in form of vouchers to get discount at restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 25, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) published information regarding support for workers who have been affected by business closures or a reduction in shifts due to the effects of COVID-19. Until September 30, 2021, the income requirements for receiving employment training benefits (職業訓練受講給付金) and attendance requirements will be relaxed. From having to have a fixed monthly income of under 80,000 yen to be eligible, the requirement is relaxed to a fixed monthly income of under 120,000 yen.
type_text: for those facing reduced shifts or business closures as a result of the effects of COVID-19, the government is relaxing the income and attendance requirements necessary for receiving employment/vocational training benefits.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. description:
On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the “(1) Provision and sharing of information,” the following polices will be adopted:
“a) Provide accurate information and clear message for the public, promote awareness-raising to help change people’s behavior, and encourage calm response.
- Provide accurate and clear information
- Ensure implementation of basic countermeasures against infection
- Ensure that people do not go to workplace, attend school or leave home if they are sick
- Dissemination of guidelines for visits to medical institutions (call for prior telephone consultation)
- Prevent discrimination against infected persons, close contacts and medical personnel.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 31, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) released "a video featuring popular fashion models" "to raise awareness of COVID-19 prevention among young people."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will take effective emergency measures taking into account the characteristics of each area and provide careful explanation to the residents.”

description: From April 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has started using an illustration of "amabie," a kind of yokai, or ghost, which is believed to have the power to ward off pestilence, to call on young people for cooperation in the fight against the novel coronavirus. An awareness flyer with the illustration of amabie urging people to "stop the spread of the virus" has been posted on the ministry's website."

On April 9, 2020, Ibaraki Prefecture (Japan) initiated "a campaign called 'Clap for Carers' to show appreciation for medical personnel" by "asking people to give applause for medical workers for about 30 seconds" every day at noon.

MHLW also shares information on where to access support regarding employment.

On 21 April 2020, the Nara Prefectural Government established an "Emergency Response Call Centre" to respond to the questions and concerns of citizens in response to the amended New Influenza Special Measures Act of 2012. The original policy had no end date.

description: On April 22, 2020, the Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting (an advisory body within the Japanese Cabinet) published a document “10 points to reduce human contact by 80%” to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The "points" or recommendations are summarised in a poster. The 10 points are:  (1) Meeting family through video calling; (2) Only one member of a household visiting the supermarket and visiting during quiet times; (3) Jogging in small numbers and choosing parks that are empty; (4) Online shopping; (5) Online drinking parties; (6) Online consultations with doctors and adjust the schedule for regular check-ups; (7) Exercise such as muscle training and yoga can be at home with videos; (8) Take-away food and drinks; (9) Work from home; and (10) Have conversations while wearing masks.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On April 22, 2020, at the 30th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister ABE Shinzō called upon citizens to “strictly avoid going out to crowded places and putting themselves at risk of contact with the virus. To that end, I ask for the cooperation of the public in refraining from going outside during this year’s Golden Week holidays and use video calls for ‘online homecomings’, rather than making an actual trip. I strongly encourage citizens to take a moment to review their behavior and I ask for cooperation in reducing such contact by 80%”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare, with the Prime Minister’s Office of Japan and the Government of Japan Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control within the Cabinet Secretariat published a poster titled “This Golden Week, let’s avoid going out!” This poster requests people in Japan to reduce contact with people by 80%, refrain from visiting family and travelling, encourages social distancing and advises people in Japan to go shopping during
quiet periods and within one’s neighbourhood, visit parks when they are quiet and go jogging when there are no crowds. Golden Week 2020 is between April 29 to May 5.

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 1) self-restraint in going out, it was stated that even where people go out to establishments where clusters are occurring or places where the 3Cs are present, these prefectures aim to alert people to take infection prevention countermeasures. These include wearing masks, maintaining distance between people, use of sanitiser and self-restraint in going out if one shows symptoms of a fever, etc

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will inform residents using the "Ten tips" "New lifestyle practices (examples)," etc. presented by the Expert Meeting.”

Note: The documents referred to are  “10 Tips to reduce contact with people by 80%” created on April 22, 2020 and “Examples of New Lifestyle Practices” created on May 1, 2020. Both were produced after meetings of the Council of Experts, translated by the MHLW ad “Expert Meeting.”

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” 

Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can “Spread awareness among residents about establishing the "new lifestyle" for preventing the spread of infections, including continuing the basic infection prevention measures.”

description:

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Health check at home” in “Requests for event participants”, it was decided that “people who fall under the following conditions should refrain from participating in the event: 1. Those who have fever symptoms (body temperature is 37.5 degrees or higher), 2. Those with cold symptoms, 3. Those who have had a medical examination or taken medicines due to fever or cold symptoms within the past 14 days, 4. Those who have visited a region or a country where the infection is spreading within 14 days.”

description:
On 17 June 2020, Nara Prefecture in the lead up to the annual monsoon season/ rainy season during which Japan is prone is disasters, shared on their website evacuation guidelines and procedures. Furthermore, these guidelines include recommendations on how to prevent the spread of covid-19 during evacuation and refuge. 

In addition to basic stockpiling, Nara Prefecture asks citizens to prepare: masks, a thermometer, plastic bags, disinfectant solution/ hand sanitiser, wet tissues and towels.

In evacuation shelters, they ask citizens to wear masks, practicing good hygiene such as hand washing and cooperate with others in the shelter. To support this, the Prefecture has attached guides on hand washing,  hand washing without water, cough etiquette and hygiene management of shelter toilets. 

This policy includes and supports material produced by the National Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 18, 2020, at the 38th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Japan’s Prime Minister ABE Shinzō announced that “tomorrow, we will introduce a contact-tracing app and further strengthen counter-cluster measures. If people who install the app spend more than a certain amount of time in close proximity to one another, that information will be recorded, and if one of them tests positive, a notification will be automatically sent out to the others. The app does not gather personal information and it can be used with peace of mind. We hope that as many people as possible will use the app”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 19, 2020, the Japan Tourism Agency, that exists under the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism announced the development of guidelines called “New Travel Etiquette - Avoid the risk of infection to have a safe and enjoyable journey” by the Travel Liaison Committee. The Travel Liaison Committee consists of industry bodies related to the travel industry. 

The “New Travel Etiquette” guidelines were published on the website of the Japan Association of Travel Agents. 

The guidelines list precautions under five categories: The Basics of the New Style of Travel; Travelling/ Moving; During meals;  Accommodation; Tourist Attractions; and Shopping.

On September 29, 2020 new posters were created. They consist of four individual posters for different situations: Transportation/ Eating and Drinking during Travel/ Accommodation/ Visiting Tourist Facilities and Shopping. As well as a second version of the general guidelines poster, which highlights six key points travellers should remember to contribute to enjoyable travels for everyone. 
 UPDATE: The policy remains the same, but new documents were added on September 29, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

　"The new coronavirus contact confirmation application "COCOA" of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is a smartphone application that allows you to receive notifications about the possibility of contact with a person infected with a new coronavirus infection."

description:
On June 25, 2020, the review committee session of experts of the National Institute of Technology and Evaluation of Japan (NITE) "held its fifth (final) meeting and decided that the following disinfection substances are effective at removing the novel coronavirus.
(1) Surfactants: Sodium linear alkylbenzene sulfonate (0.1% or more); Alkyl glycoside (0.1% or more); Alkylamine oxide (0.05% or more); Benzalkonium chloride (0.05% or more); Benzethonium chloride (0.05% or more); Dialkyldimethyl ammonium chloride (0.01% or more); Polyoxyethylene alkylether (0.2% or more); Pure-soap component (potassium salts of fatty acids; 0.24% or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020); and Pure-soap component (sodium of fatty acids; 0.22% or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020).
(2) Hypochlorous acid solution (at chlorine concentration of 35ppm or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020)."
Accordingly, on June 26, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced the results and published several explanatory materials "while NITE posted a list of detergents containing these surfactants on its website. [...] METI hopes that many of the general public will make use of these materials."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan launched V-RESAS (https://v-resas.go.jp/), an online platform and tool that visualize "near-real-time consumer behavior data. This information is being used to inform planning and decision-making for COVID-19 business recovery at the firm and government levels."

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo," declaring that the "current situation is not as tense as it was in April, when the government declared a state of emergency over the pandemic." Prime Minister Abe Shinzō "called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo." ""We've been closely monitoring the infection situation with a high sense of tension," Abe said. He called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 22, 2020, the Government of Japan kicked off the "Go To Travel campaign", a discount travel campaign. The campaign will be financed with ¥1.35 trillion yen "to promote domestic travel by anyone to any destination [within Japan] they wished with an up to a 50 percent discount via deals and vouchers. [...] But after a spike in coronavirus cases in Tokyo, the government announced a sudden decision to exclude travel to and from the capital." "The government hopes to support the tourism industry, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, while taking care not to spread the virus further. Travel and accommodation businesses are required to take full precautions."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) efforts by local government within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage local governments to implement the following policy: make use of opportunities when restaurants, etc register for or renew their business permits to distribute and make businesspeople aware of guidelines

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that, given the difficulty of obtaining non-contact thermometers, event organizers should thoroughly take every possible means (including leaflets, notifications and homepage updates) to urge event participants to take their own temperature at home. The participation of persons who do not measure their temperature will not be permitted.

description: On August 27, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced the opening of the Foreign Residents Support Center (FRESC) help desk from September 1, 2020. The help desk will "accept telephone consultations for foreigners who are having troubles such as having lost their jobs due to the new coronavirus." The consultation and the call fee are free. The service will be provided from Monday to Friday (9am-5pm) in 14 languages (Japanese, Portuguese, Spanish, Tagalog, Chinese, English, Vietnamese, Chinese, Nepalese, Thai, Indonesian, Burmese, Khmer and Mongolian).

description: On September 29, 2020 additional “New Travel Etiquette” documents were created and shared on the website of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, created by the Travel Liaison Committee. The new posters break down the guidelines into four various situations: Transportation/ Eating and Drinking during Travel/ Accommodation/ Visiting Tourist Facilities and Shopping. The second version of the general guidelines poster highlights six key points travellers should remember to contribute to enjoyable travels for everyone.

These include a summary of contact details for various regional bus associations and a poster by the Nihon Bus Association (NBA) to assuage student concerns about infection risk on buses.

description: On October 16, 2020, the Governor of Hokkaidō (Japan) SUZUKI Naomichi called for awareness of human rights in relation to the novel coronavirus. In his addressment of Hokkaido residents, the Governor stated that "acts such as discrimination and bullying should never occur, and are not tolerated." To reduce the occurrence of COVID-related bulling in schools, posters requesting students "not to engage in human rights violations such as discrimination and bullying related to the new coronavirus infection" have been distributed across elementary, junior high, and high schools.

description: On December 28, 2020, at the 50th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Japan’s Prime Minister SUGA Yoshihide announced that “With regard to these coronavirus variants, there are three points that I want the citizens to know. First is its high degree of transmissibility. According to the UK government’s assessment, the new variant in the UK may be up to 1.7 times more infectious than the one we have been battling until now. Some experts point out that in the UK, many versions of novel corona viruses have been replaced by this new variant. Second is on the effectiveness of vaccines. At this point in time, as far as we know, there is no evidence showing that the vaccines currently being given overseas do not work on the new variant. Third, preventive measures against infection remain fundamentally the same as the ones we have been using until now. I ask the citizens to take preventive measures such as wearing masks and washing their hands even more thoroughly, to refrain from attending gatherings, and to spend the New Year’s holidays quietly”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “Requests to residents of the prefecture (Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law)”, Fukuoka Prefecture requested residents to “thoroughly implement basic infection prevention measures such as ‘hand hygiene such as hand washing’.” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage. Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government requested residents, when “going to eateries, [to] try to go to places that have the sticker [of Aichi Prefecture], as they are taking measures against preventing the spread of the infection” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021. UPDATE: On March 10, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 21, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage.” Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government requested residents to “be careful not to infect those who tend to get seriously ill, such as elderly people, people with pre-existing conditions, or pregnant women.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021. UPDATE: On March 10, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 21, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, the Cabinet Secretariat, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries and other relevant ministries will coordinate and, with regards to the infection prevention measures requested by the government, will take necessary measures so that restaurants can more easily convince customers to comply with these measures.

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, the Cabinet Secretariat, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries and other relevant ministries will exert influence in order to promote the creation and popularization of authorization systems developed independently by industry groups and local governments.

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that though each health centre has worked hard on proactive epidemiological surveys based on the priority levels shown in the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare’s 20 November, 2020 office communication, it is necessary to strengthen responses and develop a response to mutant strains in order to improve the infection situation. For this purpose, while proactively making use of IHEAT and based on the point of view of responding to mutant strains, the strengthening of proactive epidemiological surveys including so-called “In-depth proactive epidemiological surveys” will be strived for in order to estimate the source of infections.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that the list of countries/regions corresponding to mutant-endemic countries/regions will be expanded at an early stage depending on the epidemic situation of mutant strain in partner countries and test results during the quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that from the perspective of strengthening the nationwide monitoring system, the sampling rate in screening tests of mutant strains will be increased to 40% at an early stage, people infected with the mutant strain will be actively confirmed and a wide inspection will be carried out around the places of the infected people. In the future, the number of tests of autonomous bodies will be periodically monitored.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, it was stated that although the National Institute of Infectious Diseases has regularly published the evaluation and analysis of mutant strains, measures such as adding an explanation about mutant strains to “11 Knowledge regarding to the ‘Now’ of coronavirus infectious disease” will be proceeded to provide the citizens with information easy to understand.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, considering the risk of aggravation and securing of the medical care provision system, the country will steadily proceed with inoculation to medical staff and then to the elderly, those with underlying diseases, and workers at facilities for the elderly.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, the country will continue to collect and provide information on the efficacy and safety of vaccines so that citizens can make inoculation decisions based on risks and benefits. At that time, the country will also collect a wide range of domestic and foreign information on the effects of vaccination, including infection prevention effects that have not been confirmed at the approval stage to utilize them in future studies on infection spread prevention measures.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, the development of good case studies in order to promote the application of accommodation at lodging facilities will be carried out through the applied use of accommodation recuperation in cooperation with medical bodies, swift recuperation adjustments performed in parallel with proactive epidemiological testing and revisions in the use, disinfection and cleaning of lodging recuperation facilities based on patients’ infection situation.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. description: On March 19, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi announced new infection prevention guidelines valid from March 22, 2021: "Based on the current infection situation and the medical institutions, we’ve inquired experts, and they suggested that the current requests to refrain from unnecessary outings and shortening business hours may be lifted, on the premise that thorough infection prevention practices in elderly care facilities are important in improving the current situation and that necessary measures will be promptly taken if signs of the reemergence of infections become evident. Even after the request has been lifted, the prefectural government will take the following measures to prevent a reemergence of infections."

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. Beginning on March 22, 2021, the prefecture issued the following recommendation to all prefectural residents: “Choose a restaurant that display the “infection prevention” stickers, is not crowded, has adequate ventilation, sufficient distance between seats, and thorough infection prevention measures such as installing acrylic panels to prevent droplets from spreading.”

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. description: On March 23, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) "opened a phone consultation center for the new coronavirus vaccination. description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "Japan will revise an ordinance to enable the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine". From February 14, 2020, authorities will be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms. [...] Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description:
On February 13, 2020, the Government of Japan enacted that, following Cabinet Order no. 29 and 28 on the Quarantine Act, which entered into force on February 14, "the following measures stipulated in the Quarantine Act are permitted to be taken during quarantine implemented upon arrival into Japan. Suspected carriers and carriers who have no symptoms will be deemed carriers of novel coronavirus.
(1) Isolation: If it is found during quarantine that a person is a novel coronavirus carrier, a chief of a quarantine station (quarantine officer) may isolate this individual (by hospitalizing him/her at an entrusted medical institution designated for infectious diseases).
(2) Detention: If it is found during quarantine that a person may be infected with a pathogen causing novel coronavirus infection, a chief of a quarantine station (quarantine officer) may detain this potentially infected individual (by hospitalizing him/her at an entrusted medical institution designated for infectious diseases, etc. or by accommodating the individual in an accommodation facility or on a vessel)."
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On February 18, 2020, at the Eleventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe invited "the public [...] to refrain from going outside, taking leave from school or work, when experiencing symptoms of a cold, such as a fever. [...] Creating an environment that makes it easy for students and employees to take days off is crucial and I would like to ask cooperation in this regard. Making use of means like tele-working is another effective approach."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From February 19, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) called for residents with cold symptoms such as a fever to take a break from school or work and rest at home.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) a) Take the following measures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law if a patient is identified by notification of a physician or other means: the active epidemiology survey to be conducted by the public health center; and close contacts to be monitored for their health conditions and requested to refrain from going out. The local government shall use active epidemiology surveys to identify a cluster based on individual patient outbreaks in cooperation with the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare and experts, and request the necessary measures including closure of the related facilities and voluntary restraint of events if there is a possibility that such a cluster exists.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) patients with mild flu-like symptoms should stay at home unless otherwise specified, and seek medical care after consulting the call center or a family doctor, if their conditions change.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(5) border control measures,” it was agreed that, “from the viewpoint of securing medical resources in Japan, quarantine operations will be shifted, according to measures to prevent the spread of infection in Japan and systems for providing medical care.”

description:
From March 21, 2020 0:00 JST until the end of April, "all efficacy of single or multiple-entry visa issued by March 20, 2020 at Japanese Embassies or Consulates General" in the following countries “are terminated and visa exemption measures are suspended”:
- Schengen countries (Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland);
- Andorra, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Egypt, Iran, Ireland, Monaco, Romania, San Marino, the United Kingdom, Vatican.
"When entering Japan, the affected individual will need to apply for a new visa."

description: On May 13, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu “approved an antigen test kit that can detect coronavirus infections quickly. The kit will initially be supplied for use in emergency medical services and for testing of people who had close contact with those with the virus.”

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[p]erform tests at the discretion of the doctor and, if a patient is found, provide recommendations and necessary measures for admission to hospitals to provide appropriate medical care.”

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[e]stablish a system for those with mild symptoms to be cared at home, in areas where there is a risk that an increase in patients of the Coronavirus may interfere with the provision of hospitalized medical care for other severely ill patients.”

description: On April 3, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted a policy of having asymptomatic or mildly ill patients of the COVID-19 coronavirus disease stay at home, in hotels or certain other places, in areas where infections are rapidly spreading." A notice dated April 2 by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) was sent to all prefectural governments. "The measure will not cover the elderly, those with pre-existing conditions and pregnant women."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

To that end, we will hire hotels in the private sector.”

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[i]solate a suspected case immediately and implement infection countermeasures under the guidance of public health centers, in case of suspecting a new case of COVID-19 infection from hospitalized patients or users.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
