description: On April 7, 2020, the governor of the Fukushima Prefecture (Japan) requested "[i]f you have unavoidable circumstances to come to Fukushima such as a new job or a job transfer, please refrain from going out for at least two weeks".
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 8, 2020, the Hokkaido prefectural government requested travelers arriving from prefectures under a state of emergency to quarantine for two weeks. These prefectures are Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo, and Fukuoka. Travelers and Hokkaido citizens are being informed of these isolation requirements through posters and fliers. This policy will be enacted on April 8, 2020, and last for an indefinite period of time.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Tokyo; Kanagawa; Saitama; Chiba; Osaka; Hyogo; Fukuoka

description: On April 8, 2020, Yoshinobu Nisaka, the governor of the Wakayama Prefecture (Japan), asked inbound travellers from COVID-19 hotspots (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka) to self-quarantine at home for two weeks. He also asked individuals who recently moved into the prefecture from the COVID-19 hotspots for job transfers.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka

description: The government of the Gifu Prefecture (Japan) requested residents avoid going out from April 10 until May 6, 2020. "[R]egardless of the time of day or night, day of the week, except when absolutely necessary to maintain your livelihood, such as to visit medical institutions, go to work, and to obtain food, pharmaceuticals, and goods necessary to sustain your life."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 10, 2020, the government of the Aomori Prefecture (Japan) requested all inbound travellers from prefectures under a state of emergency (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka) to self-quarantine for two weeks.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Japan,  Apr.10 Aomori government requests "all travelors coming from prefectures under state of emergency [Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka] to self quarantine" for two weeks.
 UPDATE: Before the request for self-quarantine was targeted towards people from abroad (unspecified countries or areas with high rates of infected people), now the measure was expanded targeting people from prefectures under state of emergency (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 13, 2020, the government of the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that those returning to Yamaguchi from a homecoming or a business trip that involved staying overnight must refrain from non-essential travel for 2 weeks, stay home, and practice social distancing from their family.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Oita Prefecture advised from April 15 until May 6 that anyone who has been "abroad" or "travelled to designated red zones" of Tokyo, Osaka, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Hyogo or Fukuoka Prefectures should "refrain from going outdoors for non-essential, non-urgent matters and keep a record of your health for 2 weeks. In the case of suspected infection, immediately consult the closest health centre". UPDATE: Original quarantine policy had undefined end date, but now set to May 6. Furthermore, quarantine initially applied to those who had travelled abroad or to Tokyo or Osaka. But now also applies to anyone who travelled from "designated red zones" in Japan.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Since April 15, 2020, at Tokyo Police Academy (Japan), a student "who tested positive for COVID-19 has prompted the school to halt all classes and order its entire student body to remain in their own dormitory rooms and self-study until further notice".
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 16, 2020). In order to guarantee (3.4) Medical Care, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) “will secure a flexible medical provision system in each region, responding to the spread of infection,” by “establish[ing] a system for those with mild symptoms to be taken care of at home in prefectures where an increase in patients may risk the medical care for severely ill patients in hospitals.”

description: On April 1, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzō announced that "all arrivals to Japan from the rest of the world, including Japanese nationals, [will] be quarantined for two weeks" from April 3, 2020, stating that "we will request individuals, including Japanese nationals, entering Japan from anywhere in the world to stay for 14 days at a place designated by the Quarantine Station Chief, and refrain from using public transportation." description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Requests in case of an infected person at the event” in “Requests for event participants”, it was decided that “if the participants had a close contact with an infected person, they should stay at home for about 14 days after contact.”
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 12, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) announced that it was relaxing its conditions for permitting the hospital release of those infected with COVID-19. Regarding asymptomatic patients, it was decided that if at least 6 days have elapsed after a PCR test result is taken and the patient tests negative in two consecutive PCR tests taken with an interval of at least 24 hours, the asymptomatic patient will be permitted to leave the hospital.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 12, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) announced that it was relaxing its conditions for permitting the hospital release of those infected with COVID-19. Rather than having to remain in hospital for a minimum of 14 days after showing signs of infection, patients will only be required to remain in hospital for 10 days on the condition that symptoms (such as a fever) have improved over a 72 hour period.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 8, 2020, it was announced that "a Maritime Self-Defense Force unit stranded in Djibouti for around three months due to the COVID-19 pandemic will return to Japan in early July." "They will be flown back to Japan after a new unit, which consists of 60 or so personnel, arrives as early as mid-June to take over their duties."

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked high-risk contact​ individuals to stay at home and monitor their health for two weeks, even if their PCR test is negative.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Definite communication with participants and cooperation with investigations by government bodies in the event of infections”, it was stated that there is a possibility that individual event participants who cooperate with health centre investigations or become high-risk contacts may be requested to stay at home for 14 days after having come into contact with an infected participant.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 6, 2020, Japan's Ministry ofDefense (MOD) announced that that 28 Ground Self-Defense Force (GSDF)members became infected with COVID-19 during training held at Asaka Military Base. As a result, the infected individuals were placed under quarantine in hospital and hotels. The total number of affected GSDF members placed under quarantine was given as 400 persons.

description: On January 8, 2021, the Government of Japan announced that "all arrivals in Japan, including Japanese nationals, would be obliged to provide certification they tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure as well as take another test upon arrival at a Japanese airport." "Authorities will ask people who can't submit certifications to self-quarantine at designated accommodation facilities and take tests on their third day in Japan." The measure will be enforced from January 13, 2021 and be effective "until a second state of emergency [...] is lifted. The government said the emergency declaration will run" through February 7, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description: On January 8, 2021, the Government of Japan announced that "all arrivals in Japan, including Japanese nationals, would be obliged to provide certification they tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of departure as well as take another test upon arrival at a Japanese airport." "The entrants will also be asked to self-quarantine at home or elsewhere for 14 days after arriving in Japan." The measure will be enforced from January 13, 2021 and be effective "until a second state of emergency [...] is lifted. The government said the emergency declaration will run" through February 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents with a fever to “call your doctor or health center for instructions on where to go” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents with a fever to “call your doctor or health center for instructions on where to go” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021. UPDATE: On February 2, 2021, according to the extension of a state of emergency for Aichi Prefecture enacted by the Government of Japan, the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents with a fever to “call your doctor or health center for instructions on where to go” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021. UPDATE: On February 22, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki began discussions with Japan’s Minister for Economic Revitalization NISHIMURA Yasutoshi to lift the national-level declaration of emergency for Aichi Prefecture by February 28, 2021. Accordingly, the requested period for this measure has been shortened to February 28, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, immigrants from countries where mutant strains are endemic are required to  1) wait at a designated facility for 3 days after entering the country, 2) conduct additional tests on the 3rd day after entering the country, 3) have the health condition checked for 14 days after entering the country.
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, 2021, the Government of Japan published the “Response to the novel coronavirus infectious disease after the cancellation of the state of emergency,” in effect after March 21, 2021. In this framework, regarding the follow-up measures by Immigration Health Confirmation Center, it was stated that the country will expand the target of the measures to all arrivals and thoroughly carry out the health observation and order arrivals to wait at home by confirming their location information and condition throughout video call and doing patrol in case of being unable to contact with arrivals for 3 days or more.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. Beginning on March 22, 2021, the prefecture issued the following recommendation to all prefectural residents: “Please refrain from going out or traveling, if you have symptoms such as fever.”

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. description:

1. "Thoroughly carry out precautionary measures (e.g. handwashing, good cough etiquette) in an out of the office and during commute" 
2. "Proactively incorporate telecommuting, staggered work hours and commute on bicycle"

On April 13, 2020, the Ghibli Museum (Mitaka City, Tokyo Prefecture) announced an indefinite extension of its closure, originally planned until April 28, 2020, stating that "[i]n response to requests from the Japanese government and local authorities regarding the increasing coronavirus spread, the museum will further extend the temporary closure which was scheduled to end on April 28th, 2020. The museum reopening and ticket sales will be announced on the museum official homepage, Twitter, LINE and LAWSON ticket homepage when it is determined safe to resume operations." UPDATE: "In response to requests from the Japanese government and local authorities regarding the increasing coronavirus spread, the museum will further extend the temporary closure which was scheduled to end on April 28th, 2020."

description: Fukuoka Prefecture from April 14 to May 6, 2020 requests the closure of "commercial facilities", which are service operating stores excluding those selling daily necessities. If commercial facilities are above 1,000 metres squared, they are requested to close under the Special Measures Enforcement Law. If the facilities are between 100 metres squared and 1,000 metres squared, then they are requested to cooperate and close anyway. But facilities can can stay open if they are less than 100 metres squared and have taken "appropriate infection prevention measures".

description:
On April 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 16, 2020). In order to guarantee (3.3) Pandemic Prevention, “businesses engaged in operations essential for ensuring the stability of people’s lives and the national economy (exemplified in the attachment), are required to continue their operation, depending on the characteristics of the businesses, while fully taking measures to prevent the spread of infection. The Government and designated prefectures will work to establish a help desk for business operators, secure logistics, and ensure a robust lifeline system, etc., in order to support smooth activities of these businesses.”

This includes:
-  "Businesses by medical personnel for treatment of other severe diseases."
- "Life support businesses for people who need assistance (especially for the elderly and disabled).”
- "Businesses which provide essential services for those who are staying at home.”
- "Businesses, at the minimum level, who provide essential services to maintain corporate activities during the period of a state of emergency."
- "Business operators for whom it would be difficult to stop production due to the characteristics of the equipment (eg. blast furnaces and semiconductor factories).”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) has requested all related businesses to take leave as described in Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Act on Special Measures against Countermeasures against New Influenza, etc., announced on April 20. 

"From April 16th to May 6th, Reiwa, the "Emergency Declaration" was issued to all prefectures, and we are strongly calling for the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unnecessarily and urgently. There is concern about an increase in the inflow of people from neighboring prefectures, which are expanding rapidly, to entertainment and amusement facilities."

description: On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The Prefecture asks that from April 23rd to May 6th, certain facilities suspend their activities in accordance with Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law. These include: recreation facilities, exercise and amusement facilities, theaters, private cram schools, driving schools, meeting/ exhibition facilities, commercial facilities other than stores that sell daily-necessities (essential goods).
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Although some facilities were asked to suspend their activities between 23 April and 6 May (which encompasses Golden Week), some are asked to remain open. Facilities that are requested to continue operating include: medical facilities, facilities for daily necessities (encompassing wholesale markets, grocery stores, essential goods sections in department stores, hardware stores, supermarkets, convenience stores), accomodation facilities, transportation, factories, financial institutions (banks, stock exchanges, insurance companies), media organisations, funeral homes, public baths, pawnshops, veterinarians, beauty salons, laundromats and garbage disposal related facilities.

However, these facilities/ services are asked to implement appropriate infection control measures or encourage remote work where possible. 

Restaurants and other hospitality businesses (including taverns) are also allowed to open, but with infection control measures and are asked to shorten opening hours and terminate the sale of alcoholic beverages at 7pm.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Facilities that are requested to continue operating include: medical facilities, facilities for daily necessities (encompassing wholesale markets, grocery stores, essential goods sections in department stores, hardware stores, supermarkets, convenience stores), accomodation facilities, transportation, factories, financial institutions (banks, stock exchanges, insurance companies), media organisations, funeral homes, public baths, pawnshops, veterinarians, beauty salons, laundromats and garbage disposal related facilities.

However, these facilities/ services are asked to implement appropriate infection control measures or encourage remote work where possible. 

Restaurants and other hospitality businesses (including taverns) are also allowed to open, but with infection control measures and are asked to shorten opening hours and terminate the sale of alcoholic beverages at 7pm.
type_sub_cat: Insurance; reinsurance; and pension funding except compulsory social security

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy
of Japan NISHIMURA Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "issued guidelines on what kind of steps governors can take to get business owners that continue to ignore government requests to suspend their operations." "The guidelines say governors are authorized to issue stronger "requests" or "instructions" to those who refuse to comply with initial requests without legitimate reasons. The names and addresses of the businesses given such stronger warnings will be disclosed online or by other means."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan's Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled "Regarding Preventing the Spread of Novel Coronavirus in Shopping Districts and Supermarkets, etc". In this document it was stated that prefectures where it is judged that people are gathering in large numbers in supermarkets, these prefectures would call on the relevant businesses to take the following policies:
* Implement socially-distanced queuing when entering the business and paying
* Disinfection/sterilization of shared spaces, thorough implementation of hand sanitiser when entering and leaving
* Ensure space when talking, erect partitions when facing each other
* When the business becomes crowded, appropriately implement entry restrictions and one-way guidance in the establishment.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 24, 2020, the Hokkaidō Prefectural Government (Japan) requested that all supermarkets enforce special "infection prevention measures" from April 24, 2020 until May 6, 2020. Supermarkets are recommended to "set a special shopping time for only the elderly, those with disabilities, pregnant women, etc.; limit the number of shoppers in the store at once by setting a fixed number of grocery baskets, carts, etc.; cancel any special advertisements or times/dates with point advantages; close eat-in spaces, enlarge bagging areas." Supermarkets are also advised to "call for caution from shoppers by hanging flyers or banners with information about the Three C's; use colored cones to enforce social distancing."

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On April 25, the Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) announced this: 
"To the citizens of the Yamaguchi prefecture, in order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, refrain from going out, except for those who need to visit the hospital, purchase food, medicines and daily necessities, and keep outdoor activities such as exercise and walking. 

On the other hand, it has been pointed out that it is necessary to prevent infections in places such as supermarkets, shopping malls, and parks that are used by many people. Please take note of the following and cooperate with us in preventing the spread of infections.
* Keep the number of people small and avoid crowds, and keep the distance between people appropriately.
* Observe the request to prevent infection at the place of use."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

On April 25, 2020, the Hokkaidō Prefectural Government (Japan) requested "businesses to close or limit operations" from April 25, 2020 until May 6, 2020. The specific facilities and businesses requested to close are "entertainment facilities, such as cabaret or night clubs; sports and recreation facilities, such as gymnasiums; performance and meeting/exhibition facilities, such as theaters or museums; commercial facilities, such as any shops or storefronts with services/goods unrelated to daily necessities; educational facilities, such as universities and cram schools."

On April 21, 2020, the government of the Akita Prefecture (Japan) requested non-essential businesses to close from April 25 until May 6, 2020. Facilities subject to the requests include hostess bars, karaoke parlors, game arcades, movie theaters and pachinko parlors. Restaurants, including izakaya pubs, will be asked to stop serving alcohol at 7 pm and close at 8 pm.

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks."
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (2) Designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that in relation to amusement centres these prefectures will make appropriate judgements while keeping these venues’ ease of generating the 3Cs and infection situation in mind. However in the event that prefectures, because of the thorough implementation of infection prevention measures,judged these facilities to not be environments where the 3Cs might easily arise, it will be possible for them to consider relaxing or lifting restrictions on the use of facilities for these venues. These infection prevention measures include calling for customers not to speak loudly and lowering the volume of background music and machines, ensuring space between people (2 meters where possible), sanitising when customers move places, the use of masks and ensuring an environment where staff can ensure that customers are not speaking loudly amongst themselves.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

The types of facility in question include bars, sports gyms, music venues, night clubs, karaoke boxes and restaurants.

description: On May 1, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced that the operation of Ferry Zamami will be suspended every Tuesday but that the High-Speed Queen Zamami ferry service will be restored every Tuesday. Schedules have been re-arranged to enable day trips to Okinawa Main Island. Moreover, the route to Aharen (which connects Zamami Island to Tokashiki Island) will be suspended. These measures will be effective from May 11, 2020. UPDATE: Change on suspension schedule.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Transportation (land; water and air)") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On May 14, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, 経団連) released guidelines "for protecting workers from COVID-19 are expected to be referred to when companies resume business activities while taking precautionary measures, following the government's lifting of the coronavirus state of emergency for most of the country's 47 prefectures. The guidelines are intended for long-term use at least until treatment for the disease is established and a vaccine is developed." Moreover, it "called on member companies to introduce a four-day workweek system to reduce coronavirus infection risks" and suggested "further promotion of remote working, staggered commuting and social-distancing measures in workplaces." Keidanren asked companies to "take measures, keeping in mind that steps taken at workplaces will lead to the prevention of a further spread of the virus across the entire society."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate ‘4) Going to workplaces’ it was decided that ‘i) Particularly in Prefectures under Specific Cautions (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Hyogo), working in rotations at workplaces that require employees to come to work and teleworking will be strongly encouraged to reduce contact, including aiming for a "70 percent reduction in employees coming to work.”’

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that, as outlined in the Basic Policies, prefectures will call for the necessary co-operation from the managers of facilities where clusters are occurring or where the 3Cs are present, based on the infection situation. This co-operation can include the implementation of distancing measures between people, ventilation and the use of sanitiser.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was stated as an example that with regard to customers not wearing masks and close contact among employees at restaurants and beauticians, prefectures would encourage such policies as the use of masks or faceguards and sanitiser, the use of partitions, space between seating (1 meter, 2 meters if possible) and using half capacity in relation to spaces with a fixed capacity
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 1) self-restraint in going out it was decided that, regarding going to businesses like medical institutions, nurseries and elderly care facilities where clusters have occurred but are requested to continue operating as per the addendum to the Basic Policies, people will not be urged to avoid these facilities but will need to thoroughly take interpersonal infection prevention countermeasures.

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, workplaces will be encouraged to put thorough measures in place to prevent infections and avoid the 3Cs.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, businesses engaged in work essential for ensuring the stability of people's lives and the national economy (examples given in the attachment) as well as businesses supporting such work, must continue operating, depending on the characteristics of the businesses, while taking comprehensive measures to prevent the spread of infections, including measures to avoid the 3Cs.

From the attachment: Businesses engaged in essential work include those: Maintaining Medical System; Continuing to protect those in need; Securing stable lives of the people; Maintaining the stability of the society; and Others (those who will have difficulty stopping the production line; operators who produce essentials).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to 2) self-restraint in going out, etc it was stated that, with regards to businesses where it is thought to be difficult at the current stage to reach a constant level of safety (businesses such as restaurants necessitating close proximity and music venues), businesses will be advised to continue operating as per the office communication dated May 14. These restrictions include wearing masks, disinfection and maintaining distance between people.

description: On 04-17-2020, Saitama prefecture, Japan instituted a policy recommending that establishments serving food and drink not serve alcohol after 7pm. On 05-25-2020 this policy was loosened, with a recommendation not to serve alcohol after 10pm. On 06-17-2020, this policy came to an end. UPDATE: The original restrictions instructed restaurants not to serve alcohol after 7pm. This was relaxed on 05-25-2020 to restrict serving alcohol after 10pm.

description: On January 12, 2021, the Governor of Fukushima (Japan), UCHIBORI Masao enacted prefectural-level emergency measures due to the novel coronavirus in line with the prefectural assessment to raise the stage of alert of Fukushima to stage 3. In this regard, the Governor asked all restaurants, bars and establishments serving alcohol such as karaoke bars to refrain from doing business from 8pm to 5am and not to serve alcohol after 7pm. The request will be valid from January 15, 2021 until February 7, 2021, but all establishments that will comply to the request will be able to ask for daily reimbursements starting from January 13, 2021. UPDATE: On February 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukushima (Japan), UCHIBORI Masao extended the emergency request to all restaurants, bars and establishments serving alcohol such as karaoke bars to refrain from doing business from 8pm to 5am and not to serve alcohol after 7pm until February 14, 2021.

description: On January 15, 2021, the Governor of Ibaraki Prefecture (Japan) announced a prefectural-level state of emergency due to the novel coronavirus that will be in place from January 18, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Ibaraki Prefecture requested all restaurants to refrain from doing business from 8pm to 5am. The selling of alcohol should end by 7pm. Take-out and delivery can open after 8pm. UPDATE: On February 5, 2021, the Governor of Ibaraki Prefecture (Japan) announced the decision to extend the declaration of a state of emergency from February 8, 2021 until February 28, 2021. In this regard, all restaurants are requested to refrain from doing business from 8pm to 5am and to end the selling of alcohol by 7pm (take-out and delivery after 8pm allowed) until February 28, 2021.

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested “business owners who operate eateries and other business facilities in Aichi Prefecture [to] shorten business hours.” All eateries in Aichi Prefecture should close by 8pm. Business facilities that serve alcohol should stop serving alcohol by 7pm. The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021. UPDATE: On February 2, 2021, according to the extension of a state of emergency for Aichi Prefecture enacted by the Government of Japan, the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 7, 2021.

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “Requests to businesses” and “Requests based on the Special Measures Law (Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law),” Fukuoka Prefecture requested “restaurants, coffee shops, including stalls that provide equipment and allow customers to eat and drink (excluding home delivery and take-out services), and entertainment facilities that are licensed to operate restaurants under the Food Sanitation Law, to restrict business hours to be between 5am and 9pm (excluding facilities (stores) whose original business hours are between 5am and 9pm). If the facility is expected to be used for accommodation purposes, such as an internet cafe or manga cafe, it will be excluded from the request for shortening business hours.” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “workplace attendance,” Fukuoka Prefecture requested people to “carry out measures* to prevent infection and avoid the “Three C's” (closed places, crowded places and close contact settings) and “Five situations” where the risk of infection increases in the workplace. In particular, they should be careful about “switching places” (break room, changing room, smoking room) in the workplace. (*hand washing and hand disinfection, cough etiquette, maintaining distance between employees, encouraging ventilation in the workplace, disinfecting areas touched by multiple people, refraining from going to work for employees with fever, and reducing employee travelling due to business trips, utilizing video conferencing.)” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.

description: On March 25, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) published a document titled "Guidelines to promote the suitable introduction and enforcement of teleworking". This document stated that teleworking, at the same time as being a way of working adapted to COVID-19 and the "New Normal", is also a way of working which allows flexibility in the use of working time and location. In terms of key guidelines, it was decided that consideration should be made to avoid any bias towards full time employees or employees who ordinarily commute to the office when introducing telework. Moreover, business managers are asked to reconsider how work is carried out and take steps towards introducing online meetings, creating a paperless work environment and abolishing unnecessary stamping or signing in order to smoothly implement teleworking. Businesses are also encouraged to implement measures to discourage harassment surrounding teleworking.
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an exporter’s certificate of export permission or certificate of export approval is set to expire due to a delay or other disruptions in target exports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the exporter is permitted to file a request to extend the validity period of the certificate. Please file such requests before the validity of the certificate expires."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "in cases where certificates issued by the government of Japan and other organizations under certain treaties or agreements expire, the government of Japan cannot extend the valid period of these certificates because of the restrictions under such treaties. Exporters with expired certificates are required to file requests to re-issue such certificates anew."

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an importer’s certificate of import approval is set to expire due to delays or other disruptions in target imports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the importer is permitted to file a request for an extension of the validity period of the certificate." “In filing such requests, importers are ordinarily required to submit the official document establishing the need for the extension of the certificate. However, until March 31, 2020, if it is difficult for importers to obtain such a document, importers are permitted to file an alternative document.”

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an importer’s tariff quota certificate is set to expire due to a delay or other disruption in target imports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the importer is permitted to file a request for an extension of the validity period of the certificate within a period not exceeding 30 days from the date following the expiration date of the certificate. Please file such request before the validity of the certificate expires (until March 31, 2020)." “In filing such request, importers are ordinarily required to submit a “document establishing the difficulties in making an import declaration of goods subject to tariff quota within the validity period of the tariff quota certificate. […] However, if it is difficult for importers to obtain such a document, importers are permitted to file an alternative document for the period until March 31, 2020.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "concerning the fulfillment of the permission conditions shown in a certificate of export permission for goods destined for China (e.g., reports on installation of machine tools), if the deadline of the fulfillment of the conditions is a date before March 31, 2020, the government of Japan will automatically extend the deadline to March 31, 2020,** for all exporters. Such exporters are not required to file a request to change registered data when extending the deadline. However, they are required to fulfill the conditions as swiftly as possible if they are able to execute them before March 31, 2020.”

description: Since the declaration of state of emergency on April 7, 2020, the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) have decreased "the number of people who commute to work by utilizing teleworking" and implemented "measures for double shifts in various divisions". Large-scale trainings for new personnel and large meetings are being avoided. Within its diplomatic missions abroad, MOFA has been promoting infection control measures "such as hand-washing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work". In addition, "various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary", and officials "either work at home or commute to work" according to a "split-team structure". Over-the-counter services have been affected by "shortened counter hours", the introduction of "appointment systems", and extensions to "document processing times".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan (MLIT) announced that the opening of an Ainu indigenous culture center in Hokkaido Prefecture has been postponed "for about a month" from April 24 to May 29, 2020. Its opening ceremony has also been rescheduled from April 18 to May 23, 2020. UPDATE: The opening of the National Ainu Museum "Upopoy" was originally postponed to May 29, 2020. On May 8, 2020 the Tourism Minister Kazuyoshi AKABA stated that the opening will be delayed again for a date that has not yet been determined.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement ‘3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that ‘i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Hyogo) will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks.’
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

Its opening ceremony has also been rescheduled from April 18 to May 23, 2020. UPDATE: After being delayed twice, on June 19, 2020 the Japanese Tourism Minister Kazuyoshi AKABA announced that the National Ainu Museum "Upopoy" will open on July 12, 2020. An opening ceremony will take place on July 11, 2020.

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” In this framework, Fukuoka Prefecture requested the measures for the prefecture-owned facilities be the same as ones for “Measures for facilities other from (1).” The targeted facilities are “theaters, viewing halls, movie theaters; assembly halls or public halls, exhibition halls; retail stores (more than 1,000 m², excluding places selling food, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment and other sanitary goods, regenerative medicine products or fuel and other goods specified by the Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare as indispensable goods to people’s life); hotels or inns (limited to the spaces used for meetings); sports facilities, amusement parks; museums, art galleries or libraries; entertainment facilities that are not licensed for food and beverage business under the Food Sanitation Law and stores operating a service industry (over 1,000 m², excluding daily necessities services).” Fukuoka Prefecture requested these businesses to ensure that their opening hours are “between 5am and 9pm.” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 14, 2020, the Government of Japan "decided at a cabinet meeting to postpone the "Rikkoshi-no-Rei" ceremonies for Crown Prince Akishino for the time being." The ceremonies were meant "to celebrate Crown Prince Fumihito's ascent to first in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne and had been planned" for April 19, 2020.
On April 21, 2020, it was announced that the 2020's edition of the "Hakata Gion Yamakasa", scheduled to be held in Fukuoka (Japan) from July 1 until July 15, will be cancelled.
As announced on April 24, all competitions will be canceled for the 63rd Tottori (Japan) Civic Sports Festival in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus infections.

description: On 21 April 2020, the Nara Prefectural Office announced the cancellation of the 86th and 87th food festival market. These wholesale markets were originally scheduled for April 25th and May 30th.

description: On April 26, 2020, the All Japan High School Athletic Federation "decided to cancel this year's Interscholastic Athletic Meet," (otherwise known as Inter-High School Sports Festival) scheduled to be held from August 10, 2020 to August 24, 2020 "in venues in 21 prefectures." "This year's high school meet for 30 sports was expected to bring together 30,000 people."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: "Fukuoka Prefecture announced parking-lot closures" at four parks (Ohori, Nishi, Najima Sports, Kasuga Parks) "during the Golden Week holidays" from April 29 to May 6.

On May 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced its "plan to utilize provisional release actively for foreigners detained in custody facilities before deportation due to illegal stays and other reasons." "The agency decided to utilize provisional release actively for detainees with no infection symptoms, except for those who have committed serious crimes, as custody facilities often have enclosed and congested environments involving close contact, with high infection risks. In addition, the guidelines include isolating new detainees for around two weeks and limiting visits to detainees to consular officers and lawyers."
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "2) Restrictions on holding events" it was decided that "All designated prefectures will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariatissued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (2) Designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that events, whether or not they are comparatively small (50 participants at most), need to meet the following conditions in order to be held: 1. The 3Cs should not occur in principle (2m distance between people where possible) 2. Singing, shouting and conversation in close quarters should not occur in principle. 3. If necessary, that appropriate infection prevention countermeasures (including use of masks, ventilation of indoor spaces, the installation of sanitiser equipmentand entry restrictions) are implemented.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures (all prefectures except Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Osaka and Hyogo) as part of 2) Restrictions on holding events it was decided that events can be held under the assumption that appropriate infection prevention countermeasures are taken (use of masks, use of sanitiser, avoiding crowding in waiting areas, etc). The criterion for events also include: indoor events are limited to under 100 people and half the venue’s capacity

description: On May 15, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Yamanashi (Japan) announced that "it would shut the route on its side to the top of the Japan's tallest mountain," Mount Fuji (Yoshida trail). "Usually, the Fujinomiya, Subashiri and Gotenba trails on the Shizuoka side and the Yoshida trail on the Yamanashi side open between July and September."

On March 25, 2020, the Okinawa Peace Movement Center decides that the 43rd 5/15 Peace March will be cancelled, as well as the rally on the "final day of the event". "The 5/15 Peace March is held every year to draw attention to the importance of peace."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 18, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Shizuoka (Japan) announced that "it will close all three trails on Mount Fuji on the central Japan prefecture's side this summer, following the spread of the novel coronavirus."

On May 20, 2020, "the Japan High School Baseball Federation and The Asahi Shimbun, a sponsor of the tournament, decided on the cancellation" of the summer National High School Baseball Championship, which was scheduled to start on August 10, 2020, "because of the novel coronavirus pandemic. At the same time, the prefectural tournaments to determine the 49 competing teams in the summer championship were also scrapped."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them.”
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Criteria for deciding on holding events” it was stated that between May 21, 2020 and June 18, 2020, indoor events are limited to under 100 persons or within half of the venue’s capacity.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Criteria for deciding on holding events” it was stated that between May 21, 2020 and June 18, 2020, outdoor events are limited to under 200 persons or where a sufficient amount of space can be maintained between people (2 meters as much as possible).

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Risk assessment and risk management” of “Type of infection countermeasures taken by the operators”, it was decided that “registration for event participants and limitation of the number of people joining will be carried out.”

description:
This year’s memorial events for the Great East Japan Earthquake have been canceled one after another due to the spread of the COVID-19.
Even in Iwate, the only prefecture in the country that has so far had no cases of infection, most events around the Golden Week holidays in May were canceled. Organizers are now worried that the pandemic may have a lasting impact on holding disaster-related events next year, when it observes the 10th anniversary of the deadly March 11 quake and tsunami, as operations of nonprofit organizations supporting victims are having trouble continuing their activities.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

With regards to “Criteria for deciding on holding events” it was stated that between July 10, 2020 and September 30, 2020, indoor events are limited to under 5000 persons or within half of the venue’s capacity.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (1) criteria for holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that under the assumption that the appropriate infection prevention measures are being taken, indoor events can be held with a restriction of under 5000 participants, as well as within half of the venue’s maximum capacity. description:
On July 17, 2020, the governor of the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) issued a declaration setting guidelines for mass gatherings. 

"The scale is less than 5,000 people both indoors and outdoors. When indoors, the number of participants is less than half of the capacity, and when outdoors, there is a sufficient distance between people. please. Also, if you plan to hold an event that involves the movement of people nationwide or an event that involves more than 1,000 participants, please consult the prefecture in advance."

description: On July 23, 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Restrictions on Holding Events After August 1”. description: On August 4, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that the "imperial garden party planned for the fall has been canceled to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus amid growing concern over a resurgence of infections." "Around 2,000 guests usually attend the parties at the Akasaka Imperial Gardens in Tokyo, where the emperor and empress greet and converse with those who have made notable constructions to the worlds of culture, sports and science."

description: On August 6, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) celebrated the 75th anniversary of the nuclear assault at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park. The coronavirus forced them to curtail the events, moving conferences on nuclear disarmament online, canceling or postponing related meetings and reducing the number of attendees to around 800, one-tenth of the turnout during a normal year.

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period." "Regarding trips to hometowns, Abe also called on people to refrain from events at high risks of infection, such as dining in a large group, and take extra care to protect elderly people from the virus."

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers are asked to carry out an infection risk assessment regarding the scale of the event, the venue (the state of ventilation), the event’s duration, the distance between event participants, participants’ characteristics (whether or not participants are elderly or have underlying diseases) and whether or not the number of participants is specified. Measures should be implemented as necessary after this risk assessment.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers should select facilities which comply with “Guidelines for preventing the spread of COVID-19 infections” and avoid the use of facilities where it is difficult to avoid the “3 Cs”.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that when taking applications from event participants, event organizers should grasp participants’ names and contact information in advance and when they attend in order to prepare a response if infected persons emerge among the participants. In the event that the event does not necessitate registration, event organizers should develop a system to be able to record the names and contact information of participants on the day of the event.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers should inform participants in advance about attending the event while wearing a mask and urge people to refrain from attending if they feel unwell.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers should put together a system to restrict the entry of individuals who are feeling unwell, such as those experiencing fever symptoms.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that the use of hand sanitizer should be thoroughly implemented when people enter the event venue. Moreover, suitable locations for event participants to be able to sanitize their hands during the event should also be secured.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that, in order to avoid poorly ventilated closed spaces, event organizers should carry out checks and implement appropriate use of ventilation equipment. Ventilation should be carried out regularly to bring in fresh air from outside.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers should devise methods such as establishing occupancy limits, making use of the venue’s layout and staggering entry and exit times in order to secure an environment where people will not cluster together (maintaining a minimum distance of 1 meter from each other, 2 meters if possible).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers will take steps to create an environment where event participants refrain from shouting, cheering or otherwise speaking in a loud voice.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that, in the case of events where performers speak or sing, sufficient space should be kept between the audience and performers.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that event organizers should establish an environment where it is possible for event participants to disinfect their hands.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of this document it was decided that, in the event that it is difficult to install hand sanitizer facilities, event organizers should secure an environment where participants can wash their hands with liquid soap. In the event that this is not possible, the event will not be held.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Examples of how infection measures should be implemented in the event that many people participate”, it was decided that participants’ temperature should be measured and the presence of any symptoms confirmed when people participate. People feeling unwell will not be allowed to participate.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Examples of how infection measures should be implemented in the event that many people participate”, it was decided that people who have been to the doctor or taken medicine for a fever or cold within the last 14 days will not be allowed to participate.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Examples of how infection measures should be implemented in the event that many people participate”, it was decided that individuals who have been to domestic regions or other countries where infections are spreading in the 14 days prior to the event will not be allowed to participate.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Avoiding a high risk of cluster infections”, it was decided that careful consideration should be made if any of the following types of venue are used for events given that many clusters have occurred in these types of venue: sports gyms, other indoor exercise facilities, bars, karaoke boxes, music venues, nightclubs and other such venues where food and drink is served.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Other points”, it was decided that, with regards to serving food, the sharing of food from large plates should be avoided. Rather, means such as providing packaged snacks individually should be employed.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. As part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was stated that event participants should be informed through means including event notifications, leaflets and the event homepage to come to the event wearing a mask. Moreover, regarding the details of health reports, these details should be checked before permitting participation, and individuals who have not had their temperature measured should not be permitted to participate.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Health checks” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that participants should submit health reports.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Health checks” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that even if an individual wishes to participate without having their temperature measured, a non-contact thermometer should be used where possible. However, if it is necessary that a contact thermometer be used, sufficient measures should be taken to avoid crowding such as conducting temperature checks in a separate room. After use, the contact thermometer will be disinfected with alcohol.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Entry registration” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that thorough entry management should be carried out in order to prevent contact between people.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Hand washing” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that thorough hand washing should be implemented through the use of hand sanitiser and liquid soap placed at the reception desk.

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Points of note at entry times” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that at the reception desk attention should be paid to the distance between participants (maintaining a minimum distance of 1 meter, 2 meters where possible).
