description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that hand sanitizing should be thoroughly carried out when entering the venue.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that appropriate inspections and management of ventilation facilities should be carried out to avoid a poorly ventilated closed space. Fresh air from outside should be introduced regularly.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that event organisers should create an environment where people cannot crowd together (maintaining a space of 1 meter apart, 2 meters where possible) through means such as setting the venue’s occupancy limit at half of its normal capacity and introducing staggered entry times.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that an environment where people do not shout or cheer should be created.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that thorough management and disinfection of shared items and areas which participants touch with their hands should be conducted regularly (once every 1-2 hours) using a disinfectant containing alcohol or sodium hypochlorite.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that arrangements should be made to prevent participants from mixing as much as possible through means such as using separate entrances and exits.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that event staff’s names and contact information should be grasped, and a register of their names created.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Food-related matters” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that, if providing food, means such as individually providing packaged snacks should be employed.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Appropriate environment management by lecture event organisers” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that sufficient countermeasures should be taken when providing food by maintaining space between participants (1 meter minimum, 2 meters if possible), not having participants face each other and creating an environment where conversation is kept to a minimum.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Smoking” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that, from the point of view of infection prevention, smoking should be prohibited in the venue and its surroundings.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Venue management” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that space between participants should be secured (1 meter minimum, 2 meters if possible) through means such as leaving a space between seating.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Rubbish” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that, as a general rule, bins with lids which can be closed should be used.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Venue management” as part of the “Draft Manual (Lecture and Seminar Edition)” it was decided that if an established time elapses (roughly an hour) a break should occur so that the interior of the venue can be ventilated.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Avoiding a high risk of cluster infections”, it was decided that appropriate operation and inspection of ventilation facilities should be implemented in order to avoid a poorly ventilated closed space.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Avoiding a high risk of cluster infections”, it was decided that ventilation should be carried out regularly by bringing in outside air.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Avoiding a high risk of cluster infections”, it was decided that an environment where people cannot crowd together should be created. This should be done by means such as restricting the occupancy of the venue more than it ordinarily would be and establishing staggered entry and exit times.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, published “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Avoiding a high risk of cluster infections”, it was decided that an environment which makes people refrain from shouting or cheering should be created.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that between September 1 and 30, 2020,  the maximum number of participants for indoor events will continue to be 5,000 and be up to half of the admission capacity. UPDATE: Policy extended until September 30.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on August 25, 2020 that restrictions on outdoor events will be extended until September 30, 2020. 5,000 participants or less are allowed to attend. UPDATE: Policy extended until September 30.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that organizers should continue to consult the government on events requiring nationwide movement with more than 1,000 participants. UPDATE: Policy extended until September 30.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From September 1 to 30, 2020, for events where it is expected people will move nationwide or over a wide area, or events for which it is difficult to grasp the number of participants, Fukuoka Prefecture recommends organizers to consider cancellation. UPDATE: Policy extended until September 30.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 20, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the planned exhibition "600th Anniversary Memorial-Sesshu and Kano School" (9/15-10/18), "Komura Yukitai Style" (10/30-1/3), and related projects scheduled to be held by the end of the year will be postponed due to the spread of the new coronavirus nationwide.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that where a venue has an established capacity and where the requirements for relaxing restrictions on holding events are secured, the upper limit for participants will be set at the higher number between either 5000 people or 50% of the venue’s capacity.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 22, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the annual Yamaguchi Kenjinkai World Grand Meeting, originally scheduled for autumn 2020, has been postponed after after careful consideration of the effects of COVID-19.

"It is held to gather overseas Kenjinkais in one area to strengthen bonds with Yamaguchi Prefecture and promote a network with Yamaguchi and its Kenjinkais across the world. Since the first Grand Meeting held in Yamaguchi City in 2004, there have been four Grand Meetings organized."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 28, 2020, the Okinawa government announces their intent to postpone the 7th Worldwide Uchinanchu Festival to October 2022. On September 25, 2020, it is formally decided that the event will be postponed until October 30, 2022.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Criteria for deciding on holding events” it was stated that from October 1, 2020, indoor events are limited to within half of the venue’s capacity.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020 and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Criteria for deciding on holding events” it was stated that from October 1, 2020, outdoor events are limited to the level where a sufficient amount of space can be maintained between people (2 meters as much as possible).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 22, 2020, Fukuoka City (Japan) announced that Coming-of-Age Day on January 11, 2021, which is a ceremony for new adults, will be split into two parts and livestreamed online to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The city further advises participants to install the COCOA tracking app on their phone before visiting the venue.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 31, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the Cycle Prefecture Yamaguchi Symbol Event All Yamaguchi Ride Festa 2020 Regarding "Yamaguchi Tokigagamine International Downhill" was cancelled to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On December 9, 2020, it was announced that the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) "canceled celebratory events typically held to mark" the birthday of Empress Masako, who turned 57 on December 9, "due to the novel coronavirus pandemic."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On December 25, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan SUGA Yoshihide "called on the nation to spend the year-end period quietly and refrain from traditional social activities as records for new COVID-19 cases become a daily occurrence. 'If nothing is done, we will not be able to avoid a further spread of infections [...] I would like to ask the general public to spend a quiet year-end and New Year period.'"
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 28, 2020, the Government of Japan decided "to cancel Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's visit scheduled [for January 4, 2021] to Ise Jingu, a Shinto shrine complex in Mie Prefecture, central Japan, amid the resurgence of the novel coronavirus." "It is customary for Japan's prime minister to visit Ise Jingu at the beginning of the year and hold a press conference there after worshipping at the shrine." "As the shrine visit has been canceled, Suga will hold his New Year's press conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo on the morning of Jan. 4. Suga's Ise Jingu visit will be rearranged."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 6, 2021, the Governor of Nagasaki (Japan), NAKAMURA Hōdō issued a prefectural-level special warning, requesting residents to avoid "the opportunity to have dinner when going out of the prefecture" to other prefectures from January 7, 2021 until January 17, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 14, 2021, the Governor of Mie Prefecture (Japan) SUZUKI Eikei issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus. The state of emergency will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this regard, the Governor asked residents to avoid social gatherings where a large number of people eat or drink for a long time, including lunch and dinner among relatives, due to the high risk of infection.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 14, 2021, the Governor of Mie Prefecture (Japan) SUZUKI Eikei issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus. The state of emergency will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this regard, the Governor asked residents who commute outside the prefecture for work or school to avoid gatherings where a large number of people eat or drink.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, the Governor of Kumamoto (Japan) KABASHIMA Ikuo issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus that will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Kumamoto Prefecture asked residents to refrain from eating out with “more than 5 people who you are not in regular contact with. (This also applies to having group meals in your home)”.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, the Governor of Kumamoto (Japan) KABASHIMA Ikuo issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus that will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Kumamoto Prefecture asked residents not to visit host clubs or “Kyabakura” bars which do not display the sticker certifying that they are taking infection prevention measures.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, the Governor of Kumamoto (Japan) KABASHIMA Ikuo issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus that will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Kumamoto Prefecture asked events to restrict the number of spectators. Venues were asked to limit attendees to 5000 people, or 50% of the venue’s capacity: whichever number is lowest.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, the Governor of Kumamoto (Japan) KABASHIMA Ikuo issued a prefectural-level declaration of emergency due to the novel coronavirus that will be in place from January 14, 2021 until February 7, 2021. In this framework, Kumamoto Prefecture encouraged people to work from home, or have staggered working hours.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents to “avoid dining with groups of 5 or more people. If you are dining with others, dine in a small group of people who you are always with” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents, when “attending events, [to] make sure to wear a mask and keep a distance from others” and to “refrain from talking loudly and drinking alcohol” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents not to “go to closed spaces with poor ventilation where the windows and doors are closed, crowded places where people gather closely, and places where you cannot keep a safe distance from others” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents to “be careful of infection by dining for a short time and wearing a mask when having conversations” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage. Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government requested residents to “go to eateries that are not crowded and where good ventilation and sufficient space between seats are ensured.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 26, 2021, the Governor of Aichi Prefecture (Japan) ŌMURA Hideaki announced that, “to prevent further spread of COVID-19, the Aichi Prefectural Government has declared a critical stage.” Therefore, the Aichi Prefectural Government requested residents to “avoid dining with groups of 5 or more people” and, if “dining with others, [to] dine in a small group of people [with whom one is] always with.” The requested period is 14 days, starting from March 1, 2021 through March 14, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “Requests for restrictions on holding events (until April 11, 2021) (Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law),” Fukuoka Prefecture states that for events where it can be assumed that there are no loud cheers, “5,000 people or within 50% of the capacity (up to 10,000 people), whichever is larger” can attend the event. The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 4, 2021, the Governor of Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) OGAWA Hiroshi issued an announcement on the “Continuation of requests to the prefecture’s citizens and business.” With regards to “Requests for restrictions on holding events (until April 11, 2021) (Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law),” Fukuoka Prefecture states that for events where loud cheers are expected, the number of attendees must be “within 50% of the capacity (up to 10,000 people).” The request will be valid from March 8, 2021 until March 21, 2021.

description: On March 19, 2021, Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) announced new infection prevention guidelines. Beginning on March 22, 2021, the prefecture issued the following recommendation to all prefectural residents: “Going to restaurants should be limited to a small number of people and spend no more than two hours. Do not drink heavily, wear a mask when talking, and avoid speaking in loud voices. Please do the same for gatherings with meals at private homes, etc.”

description: On March 16, 2021, Japan's Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games announced a policy for its management of spectators along the Olympic Flame relay route. It was decided that, in order to avoid COVID-19 risks and prevent mass gatherings, sections along the relay route will be skipped over if closely packed crowds of spectators are unable to disperse even after being requested to do so by event staff.

description: On February 28, 2020, Akita Prefectural Government (Japan) announced that "at this point, we do not make a uniform request for self-restraint for meetings and events, but we ask that you reconsider the necessity of holding the meeting, including cancellation, postponement, and reduction in size."

From April 17 until May 6, 2020, residents of the Aomori prefecture (Japan) are asked "to refrain from going out" for reasons that are "not necessary or urgent“ and to "refrain from going out to restaurants".

In March 2020, the Tottori Prefectural Government (Japan) introduced a “Tottori-type office system” to review the layout of office desks, such as securing the distance between employees and installing partitions between desks, for the following purposes. 

"This Tottori-type office system is one of the ways to live while preventing infectious diseases in the Tottori-type “new lifestyle”. With a little effort, you can expect to reduce the risk of infection. Please refer to it at your workplace."

description: On March 13, 2020, Japan's Cabinet Secretariat published information regarding special considerations for 2019 and 2020 graduates, prospective employees and jobseekers. It was decided that if the decision is made to hold a company briefing, businesses should encourage attendees to wear masks and wash their hands. It was also decided that businesses should make sufficient consideration for the installation of disinfectant stations and diligent ventilation.

description:
On March 24, 2020, the Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) Koichi HAGIUDA sent to local authorities and prefectural education boards guidelines on the reopening of schools. The guidelines highlight that the following three conditions and their combination must be avoided:
- closed spaces with poor ventilation
- crowded spaces
- conversations at close distances
To avoid these conditions, MEXT calls for the use of masks and implementation of good ventilation, as well as temperature checks. Hand washing and coughing etiquette must be enforced.  

Furthermore, the guidelines take into consideration students who cannot attend school because they have been identified as an infected person, or having close contacts. It calls for the prevention of discrimination, prejudice and awareness for the mental health of children. 

Teachers and faculty must also not come to school if they are sick or have close contacts.

Extracurricular activities may continue but with adjustments so that the three conditions are avoided. 

To ensure that learning is not delayed, schools may offer supplementary classes with measures in place. 

The continued suspension of the school will be depended on local school authorities and must take into account, infections within the school and the surrounding community.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 26, 2020, the Tokyo Governor KOIKE Yuriko and the governors of neighboring Chiba, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa prefectures held a joint teleconference, "urging their people to avoid leaving home for nonessential purposes, to prevent an explosive surge in COVID-19 infections."  The governors stressed avoiding crowds, poorly ventilated areas, and events in order to avoid a widespread lockdown.

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to “[p]resent appropriate measures to prevent clusters and reduce contacts, based on the local situations” and to “[c]all for cooperation in self-restraint in avoiding gatherings in closed spaces, crowded places, or close-contact settings. Pay particular attention to metropolitan areas.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 3, 2020, the government of the Iwate Prefecture (Japan) requested people to refrain from going out on weekends as wells as weekdays nights for the next two weeks: "I would like you to be cautious about your activities, such as refraining from going out for "unnecessary urgency" on weekdays during the night and on weekends for the next two weeks.“

Japan, on Mar. 30 Iwate prefecture asks (especially young people) to refrain from participating in events and to work via telework if possible: „We call for the careful action of young people who find it difficult to detect infections, refrain from events, and cooperate with the implementation of telework.“ UPDATE: Iwate govenor further more asks (especially young people) to refrain from participating in events and to work via telework if possible.

From April 24 until May 6, 2020, the governor of the Fukushima Prefecture (Japan) requests "residents to make efforts to reduce person-to-person contact as much as possible by taking actions such as going shopping with as few people as possible and to avoid the busiest opening times if it is necessary to go out with family members or children"
On April 1, 2020, the governor of the Wakayama Prefecture (Japan) asked residents to use self-restraint especially when considering when to leave home.

On April 17, 2020,  the government of Yamagata Prefecture (Japan) requested that residents practice social distancing: "[W]e request the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unless it is necessary to maintain their lives" until May 10, 2020.

Japan, on Apr. 1  Yamagata government requests young people to refrain from going out in the evenings, i.e. to visit drinking establshments and restaurants. UPDATE: In addition to avoid gatherings Yamagata government requests young people to refrain from going out in the evenings, i.e. to visit bars and restaurants.

From April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has started introducing a rotating work-shift system to ensure that its operations can continue without disruptions in the event someone within its structure becomes infected with the coronavirus." "The notification instructs all departments [...] to divide their staff members into several teams. The teams will be put to work in different times of the day or told to work at home every other day."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Apr. 03 Iwate government requests people to refrain from going out on weekends as wells as weekdays nights for the next two weeks: "„I would like you to be cautious about your activities, such as refraining from going out for "unnecessary urgency" on weekdays during the night and on weekends for the next two weeks.“ UPDATE: Iwate government furthermore requests people to refrain from going out on weekends as wells as weekdays nights for the next two weeks.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 7, 2020, Miyazato Satoru, village mayor of Zamami Island (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) published a notice that encouraged residents to avoid "3C spaces" (closed spaces, crowded places, close-contact settings).

From April 7, 2020, the Government of Japan has asked the seven prefectures placed under a state of emergency (Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama, Kanagawa, Hyogo, Osaka, and Fukuoka) "to reduce the amount of physical contact among people by 80%". 

Prime Minister Shinzō ABE has encouraged the population to "make efforts and reduce opportunities for person-to-person contact by a minimum of 70 percent, or ideally 80 percent" "for the limited period of one month between now and the end of Golden Week holidays on May 6. This includes time for us to assess its effectiveness." 

This request was made during a press conference on the April 7, 2020 Declaration of a State of Emergency.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Japan, Wakayama government requests social distancing and self-quarantine: request to „refrain from visiting any place other than your workplace or medical institution“ until May6th. UPDATE: While just adressing people to consider where to go, the request asks now for stronger self restrain (i.e. refrain from going to restaurants, telework). The timing was also set and the measure will be effective until May6th.
Japan, Govenor of Gifu requests residents to follow the measure of social distancing: "When possible, stay 2 meters apart from other people."

Japan, on Apr. 10 Yamagata government requests residents to social distance themselves: „Even within the prefecture, refrain from unnecessary activities and outing. Please be careful for your own sake and for the sake of those around you.“ UPDATE: Request to social distance in the whole prefecture without any exceptions.

Japan, Govenor of Gifu requests residents to follow the measure of social distancing: "When possible, stay 2 meters apart from other people." Gifu prefecture decides to extend the end of social distancing from May 6 to an undefined day. UPDATE: Gifu prefecture decides to extend the end of social distancing from May 6 to an undefined day.

 UPDATE: Iwate government expands the "request to refrain from going out to restaurants, and other service facilities in the downtown area“.

description:
Japan, Yamato City, Kanagawa Prefecture, has enacted and enforced the "Omoiyari Mask Wearing Ordinance" on Apr.16.
The ordinance requires citizens to be considerate and wear masks to prevent infection:
„神奈川県大和市は16日、新型コロナウイルスの感染拡大を防ぐため、マスクの着用を呼びかける「おもいやりマスク着用条例」を制定、施行した。罰則規定はない。“
type_text: The municipal government requests to wear masks outside.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On April 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 16, 2020). In order to guarantee (3.4) Medical Care, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) will “prevent nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly” by “taking every  possible precaution[ary] measure to prevent workers from being a source of infection including by thoroughly avoiding the 3-Cs.”
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Japan, in Aomori prefecture  "all citizens of the prefecture are requested to refrain from going out when they are not necessary or urgent“ and to "refrain from going out to restaurants, etc. that are accompanied by entertainment in the downtown area." by Aomori government from Apr.17 until May6. UPDATE: The timing was unsettled before and was set until May6th.

Japan, on Apr. 17 Yamagata government requests residents to social distance themselves: "[W]e request the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unless it is necessary to maintain their lives" from Apr. 17 until May 10.
 UPDATE: Measure is timed from April 17 (Fri) to May 10 (Sun).

Japan, on Apr. 17 Fukushima government requests residents to "avoid going out for any nonessential reasons. In particular, I urge you to refrain from going to nightclubs, hostess bars and the like in busy downtown areas" from Apr. 17 until May 6. UPDATE: NoFukushima government requests to refrain from going out at all (except for essential businesses) and sets a timing until May 6.

On April 23, 2020, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare, with the Prime Minister’s Office of Japan and the Government of Japan Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control within the Cabinet Secretariat published a poster titled “This Golden Week, let’s avoid going out!” This poster encourages social distancing and advises people in Japan to go shopping during quiet periods and within one’s neighbourhood, visit parks when they are quiet and go jogging when there are no crowds.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Japan, Miyagi government requests residents to limit the number of people going grocery shopping or visiting parks together to avoid congestion from Apr. 24 until May 6. UPDATE: Policy was strengthened insofar people should use a minimum number of people to go grocery shopping as well when visiting parks.

Japan, on Apr 24 Fukushima governor requests "residents to make efforts to reduce person-to-person contact as much as possible by taking actions such as going shopping with as few people as possible and to avoid the busiest opening times if it is necessary to go out with family members or children" from Apr. 24 until May 6. UPDATE: Fukushima governor requests "residents to make efforts to reduce person-to-person contact as much as possible by taking actions such as going shopping with as few people as possible and to avoid the busiest opening times if it is necessary to go out with family members or children".

On April 23, 2020, the government of Tokyo (Japan) requested residents "to limit the frequency of grocery shopping to every three days as part of steps to prevent supermarkets becoming too crowded“ from April 25 until May 6, 2020.

As announced on April 27 by the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan), public transport operators are taking the following preventive measures against infectious diseases.

"As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are encouraging airport staff to wear masks and install disinfectant solutions at airport entrances to encourage airport users to disinfect their hands.
In addition, each airline also implements measures such as wearing masks and gloves for flight attendants and ground personnel, disinfecting cabins in the cabin, and circulating air.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, bus crews wear masks to operate and guide passengers. In addition, we are implementing disinfection and ventilation inside the vehicle, as well as restrictions on the use of buses in the front row in order to keep the distance between the driver and the driver.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as employee wearing masks and installing disinfectant.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as wearing masks for employees and arousing and disinfecting trains."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will carefully avoid the "3Cs" while also taking basic measures to prevent infection, such as handwashing and maintaining social distancing between people."

description: On May 7, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "asked prefectures on the special alert to continue to keep measures in place. The government is to analyze in detail the effects of calls by central and local governments to refrain from nonessential outings and hometown visits during the spring break."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on residents of 13 prefectures where special alert for the novel coronavirus is requested to continue efforts to reduce interpersonal contact by 80 pct. The government is concerned about the possibility of citizens in the 13 prefectures - Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa, Saitama, Osaka, Hyogo, Fukuoka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi and Kyoto - relaxing their social distancing efforts."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Tokyo Prefecture; Chiba Prefecture; Kanagawa Prefecture; Saitama Prefecture; Osaka Prefecture; Hyogo Prefecture; Fukuoka Prefecture; Hokkaido Prefecture; Ibaraki Prefecture; Ishikawa Prefecture; Gifu Prefecture; Aichi Prefecture; Kyoto Prefecture

description:
Starting from May 14, 2020, Sendai city gave rules to customers in restaurants. 
• The tables should be separated by partitions to prevent splash infection, or side-by-side with a space of at least 2m (at least 1m).
Arrange the layout so that you can sit in, and open an appropriate space so that the counter seats do not stick together.
• Avoid direct layout, or devise a partition (such as acrylic plate) on the table.
• If you want to meet face-to-face with a small number of family members and caregivers, such as the elderly, infants and people with disabilities, this may be possible, but with other groups
Avoid sharing seats.
• To ensure safety between groups, keep at least 2m (at least 1m) away from other groups and keep conversations modest.
And consider recommending listening to BGM.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 16, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on people to stay alert against the new coronavirus." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi stated that "carelessness can lead to a new wave of the outbreak, urging people not to relax efforts to contain the virus," calling on "residents of the 39 prefectures to continue containment efforts while resuming economic activities gradually. For residents of the eight prefectures where the state of emergency is still in place, Nishimura underlined the need for continued efforts to reduce contact by 80 pct."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 17, 2020, the Government of Japan "called for continued voluntary restrictions by residents of the eight prefectures where its coronavirus state of emergency remains in effect" (Hokkaido, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo). "Economic and fiscal policy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura called for these residents' continued cooperation to ensure that the state of emergency is lifted within this month. "A second wave of infections could come. People should continue voluntary restrictions without becoming relaxed about them," Nishimura said."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: Hokkaido Prefecture; Tokyo Prefecture; Kanagawa Prefecture; Saitama Prefecture; Chiba Prefecture; Osaka Prefecture; Kyoto Prefecture; Hyogo Prefecture

description: On August 28, 2020, the prefectural government of Okinawa, Japan, revised “COVID-19 Guidelines for the implementation of hosting events in Okinawa” which was first published on May 20, 2020, and has been valid since May 21, 2020. With regards to “Risk assessment and risk management” of “Type of infection countermeasures taken by the operators”, in “Measures against droplet infection”, it was decided that "the event operators will set up the event place so that event participants can keep a distance of 1 meter from each other, 2 meters if possible."
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On December 10, 2020, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published "Regarding thoroughness in infection prevention measures during school choir activities". As part of this document it was decided that, as a general rule, masks should be worn by participants in choir events. It was stated in addition that MEXT did not recommend the use of coverings like face shields and that mouth shields and other such masks with gaps were not appropriate for this policy.

description: On January 13, 2021, Aichi Prefecture (Japan), following the declaration of a state of emergency issued by the Government of Japan covering 7 prefectures, including Aichi, requested residents, when “taking public transportation such as taxis, buses, and trains, [to] always wear a mask and refrain from talking loudly” and to “be especially careful when […] taking transportation after drinking alcohol” in order not to “get infected and infect others.” The requested period is 25 days, starting from January 14, 2021 through February 7, 2021.

description: On January 15, 2021 the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) asked requests visitors to its Osaka Liaison Office to "wear a mask", disinfect hands, check their temperature and "complete an application for admission card and health questionnaire at the entrance" to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

description:
On January 29, 2021, Japan's Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) published the document "Regarding thoroughness in efforts to prevent COVID-19 infection spread in universities". This document stated that, regarding university dormitories, efforts to prevent infection should be carried out. 

These policies include conducting PCR tests on students moving into dormitories, infection prevention measures in shared spaces like bathrooms and canteens, students taking their temperature every morning and thoroughness in students wearing masks outside their rooms.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

UPDATE: On February 2, 2021, according to the extension of a state of emergency for Aichi Prefecture enacted by the Government of Japan, the requested period for this measure has been extended until March 7, 2021.
